This group of women sadly doesn't have the luxury of a bank loan due to the variety of requirements, which is why they have turned to ASDIR.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase capital to purchase more supplies

loans.name: Try Hard Group

texts.en:
This group, called Try Hard, led by Rebecca S., consists of three other members: Mabinty K., Fatmata K. and Demoh S., all local entrepreneurs in Makeni, the Northern Province headquarter town. This group has been with SMT for more than four years now, always repaying its loans on time before seeking a new one. Their businesses prosper as a result of the loans they receive from Kiva through SMT, enabling them to expand and acquire items that were previously lacking in their stalls, the same objective of their current loan request.

The leader of this group, Rebecca S., 45, is married with three children, two in secondary school and the eldest in college. Her husband, a lecturer, is primarily responsible for their schooling as tradition maintains, but Rebecca also contributes greatly towards their education and welfare. She has been selling local produce including ground-nuts, palm-oil, pepper, and onions at the town's main lorry pack for the past 20 years now.

loans.use: To buy items they currently lack for their vending stalls

loans.name: Libertador Group

texts.en:
The Libertador group is maD. up of nine women and three men who live in the Cerro San Miguel zone of Cochabamba in central Bolivia. Though they are all involved in a variety of different economic activities, the group members share the desire to get ahead, both financially and personally, and hope that this loan will help them increase their income.

Most of them are vendors who work on the street, in markets or door to door. Nelly and Doris sell cosmetics; Maria Luisa, Georgina, and Delia sell clothing; Liseth sells cell phones; Hugo has a printing business; Paola and Jose Maria sell and burn CDs; Julia sells prepared meals; Irene sells sweets; and Marco rents out sound systems. All have between two and ten years of experience in their respective businesses.

Most of the group members plan to use their Kiva loans to buy more merchandise to sell (foodstuffs, school supplies, etc.). This is the group's second loan cycle with AgroCapital.

loans.use: Buy bulk merchandise to resell

loans.name: Nohemi

texts.es:
Nohemi es originaria de García Nuevo León, y se dedica a la venta de productos de belleza por catálogo.

Actualmente, solicita un préstamo por USD$475 a un plazo de seis meses para con ello resustir mercancías para la venta de productos de belleza y zapatos.

Nohemi se inició hace tres años en las ventas por catálogo debido a la necesidad de ayudar a su esposo en los gastos del hogar, en virtud de que él no cuenta con una estabilidad en su trabajo. Nohemi es casada y tiene tres hijos. Con el transcurso del tiempo Nohemi ha vendiendo productos de belleza de distintas marcas, sin embargo, hoy en día dice que ya encontró a un proveedor que le ofrece productos de mejor calidad y que le generan mayor utilidad.

¡Los invito a apoyar a Nohemi para que su negocio siga creciendo!
texts.en:
Nohemi is a native of García Nuevo León and makes a living selling beauty products via catalog. Currently, she is requesting a loan of $475, which she plans to repay within two months, so she can revamp her stock of beauty products and shoes to sell. Nohemi, who is married and has three children, started her job three years ago due to the need to help her husband with household expenses because he did not have a steady job. As time has passed, Nohemi has been selling brand-name beauty products and says she has already found a supplier who offers products of higher quality and more usefulness.

We invite you to support Nohemi so her business keeps growing!

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Revamp supply of beauty products to sell via catalog

loans.name: Las Tres Estrellas Group

texts.en:
The Las Tres Estrellas ("The Three Stars") group is maD. up of thirteen women who live in the Villa Ingenio neighborhood of El Alto, Bolivia. The group is currently in its second loan cycle. The group members are involved in a variety of businesses: selling prepared meals, bags, toast, meat, and laundry detergent, doing upholstery, running an Internet café and neighborhood stores, and working for a local mining company. The group has a wiD. range of experience: some, like Constancia, Sabina, and Gladys have just one year of experience, while others, like Bertha, Cecilia, and Janethe have more than fifteen. Segundina has been working in butcher shops for almost fifty years!

Juana is the group's president. She has two children, and works from home in her upholstery shop along with her husband, Teofilo. The treasurer, Rosalia, has two children and runs an Internet café with phone services. Janethe sells laundry detergent in the 16 D. Julio zone (the largest market in Bolivia). She has two children, and her husband, Octavio, works as a driver. The couple works hard to get ahead.

Most of the group members plan to use their Kiva loan to purchase more bulk merchandise to sell.

The group has a good dynamic. The women have worked together before with other microfinance institutions, so they all know one another very well. In their first cycle, the women repaid all of their installments without any problems, and were always responsible and punctual.

loans.use: Buy bulk merchandise to resell

loans.name: Las Pampitas Group

texts.en:
The Las Pampitas group is maD. up of eleven women and two men who know each other from their neighborhood, in the tropical Santa Cruz D. la Sierra region of eastern Bolivia. The group members are involved in a variety of different businesses: Martha does laundry, Cielo and Angel sell drinks, Nancy owns a pig farm, Yonny and Maria del Carmen sell prepared meals, Maria Ruby sells dulce D. leche, Sonia sells sandals, Leonela does embroidery, Susana owns a bakery, Maria Eugenia sells hamburgers, and Claudia sells Yambal cosmetic products. The women have various levels of experience working in their respective areas, anywhere from two to twenty-four years.

Most of the group members plan to use the loan to buy more merchandise to sell or materials/ingredients to make their respective products. Most of them have previous experience with group loans at other financial institutions.

loans.use: Buy bulk merchandise to resell

loans.name: Luz Y Vida Group

texts.en:
The Luz y Vida (Light and Life) group is made up of 13 people, of whom four are men and nine are women. All of the group members live in the same zone of Munaypata, a neighborhood in El Alto, BoliV.. The members are involved in different economic activities, such as selling athletic and American clothing, food, and sweets. Some of the men in the group work as drivers.

Betty is the group president. She has three children, and works as a street vendor selling large shopping bags and sweaters. Her husband is a contractor. The treasurer, Jannett, is single and sells handicrafts; she is also studying. The secretary, Esther, has one son and runs a lunch counter, which does very well.

The group gets along very well. The women worked together previously with another financial institution, so they know each other very well. Most of the group members plan to use this loan to increase their inventory of products so that they can earn more money.

loans.use: Buy bulk merchandise to resell

loans.name: Marcela

texts.es:
Marcela is 34 years old and married with 5 children who are 1, 6, 8, 10, and 12 years old. Her husband helps her by cultivating potatoes and helping her look after the children. The couple grows and sells their potatoes in the Chapisirka region of Cochabamba in central Bolivia. They have been doing this for many years and have a lot of experience in the area. Marcela owns the land they farm on, as well as 10 donkeys, which she uses to transport potatoes.

Whenever there are no potatoes to harvest (which can happen for a variety of reasons), Marcela buys potatoes in bulk and then resells them. Since she has so much experience, she knows where to get the best prices. She will use this loan to buy potatoes in bulk at the market price.

Though there is stiff competition in potato sales, since Marcela lives in an area with many potato farmers, she has been able to dominate a portion of the potato market so her sales are steady. This will be her sixth loan with AgroCapital. She paid off all of her previous loans on time, though it should be mentioned that she did pay some of her installments behind schedule due to some problems with potato planting.
texts.en:
Marcela is 34 years old and married with 5 children who are 1, 6, 8, 10, and 12 years old. Her husband helps her by cultivating potatoes and helping her look after the children. The couple grows and sells their potatoes in the Chapisirka region of Cochabamba in central Bolivia. They have been doing this for many years and have a lot of experience in the area. Marcela owns the land they farm on, as well as 10 donkeys, which she uses to transport potatoes.

Whenever there are no potatoes to harvest (which can happen for a variety of reasons), Marcela buys potatoes in bulk and then resells them. Since she has so much experience, she knows where to get the best prices. She will use this loan to buy potatoes in bulk at the market price.

Though there is stiff competition in potato sales, since Marcela lives in an area with many potato farmers, she has been able to dominate a portion of the potato market so her sales are steady. This will be her sixth loan with AgroCapital. She paid off all of her previous loans on time, though it should be mentioned that she did pay some of her installments behind schedule due to some problems with potato planting.

Translated from Spanish by Joanna Silverman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy potatoes

loans.name: Alvaro Benjamin

texts.es: El señor Alvaro Benjamín Menchú Vásquez de 38 años de edad, Casado actualmente reside en la 8va. Calle 9-25 de la zona 2, de Totonicapán. Hace más de trece (13) años viene trabajando de comerciante y elaborando chumpas, güipiles y otras prendas típicas con variedad de estilos y diseños. Entregando su producción en Antigua Guatemala y Solóla  y   hace unos  años se acercó a las oficinas de Asdir para solicitar un crédito para implementar su capital y surtir su mercaderia con el credito anterior crecio economicamente y se desarrollo de otra manera con su negocio  viendo que dia a dia va mejorando su negocio y su nivel de vida y de su familia hoy nueva mente se ve con la necesidad de otro credito  que será invertido para ampliar su capital de trabajo y mejorar su producción, ya que se acerca la feria titular de nuestro pueblo para que el pueda producir más y así obtener buenas ganancias  para el beneficio del mismo. Ya que también se acerca el fin de año y así con el crédito solicitado pueda exponer su trabajo a los turistas que visitan nuestro país y así ellos puedan ser acreedores de esta producción tan tradicional de nuestro país.
texts.en:
Mr. Alvaro Benjamín Menchú Vásquez, a 38-year-old married man, currently lives on 8va. Calle 9-25 in zone 2 of Totonicapán. He has been in business for over 13 years, making jackets, güipiles (traditional Guatemalan dresses) and other traditional apparel in assorted styles and varieties. He sells his merchandise in Antigua Guatemala and Solóla. A few years ago, he visited the Asdir office to request a loan in order to increase his capital and stock up on merchandise. With his previous loan, his business was able to grow financially and develop in a different way. Upon noticing that both his business and his family’s standard of living have been improving on a daily basis, he once again feels the need to obtain another loan that will be invested in increasing his work capital and improving production. Because the town fair is approaching, he would like to be able to produce more and earn more profits for his own benefit. Furthermore, the end of the year is coming up, and with this loan he wants to display his work to the tourists who visit the country so that they can purchase our traditional clothing.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase supplies to make clothing

loans.name: Yeni

texts.es:
Yeni es soltera, tiene 20 años de edad, estudió quinto de secundaria y vive en la Comunidad de Machacmarca, Distrito de Pilcuyo, Provincia del Collao.

Aproximadamente dos años es socia del Banco Comunal Ciudad Nueva – Machacmarca,  a los 17 años de edad comenzó con la venta de sabanas, con su primer crédito compró 01 fardo de sabanas, ella vende los días jueves y viernes en la ciudad de. Puno.

Con este crédito de S/. 1,000.00  Nuevos Soles que pagará en 04 cuotas tiene planificado comprar 02 fardos de sabanas.

Su visión es postular a la Policía  Nacional.
texts.en:
Yeni is 20 years old, single, has a high-school education and lives in the community of Machacmarca. At age 17, she started selling sheets, and about two years ago she became a member of the local community bank. With her first loan, she purchased a large bundle of sheets, which she sells Thursday and Friday in the city of Puno. With the loan she is currently requesting, which she plans to repay in four months, she plans to purchase two more large bundles of sheets. Her dream is to apply for the National Police.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase sheets at wholesale

loans.name: Alejandra

texts.es:
Alejandra es casada, progenitora D. cuatro hijos, estudió primaria completa y tiene 63 años D. edad, vive en la comunidad D. Machacmarca.

Es socia del Banco Comunal Ciudad Nueva D. la comunidad D. Machacmarca, Distrito D. Pilcuyo, Provincia del Collao – Puno; hace dos años empezó con su primer crédito D. S/. 300.00 Nuevos Soles, incrementando su capital para comprar una vaca con 
 S/. 400.00 Nuevos Soles, ella se dedica a la compra y venta D. vacas en las ferias D. Pilcuyo, Acora  e Ilave.

Con este crédito D. S/. 2,000.00 Nuevos Soles, que pagará en 04 cuotas, comprará 02 vacas por el valor D.   S/. 900.00  a S/. 1,000.00 Nuevos Soles.

Su visión es tener su establo D. vacas porque le trae suerte y le va mejor en el negocio y no así con los toros.
texts.en:
Alejandra is a 63-year-old married mother of 4 children. She completed elementary school and lives in the community of Machamarca. She is a member of the Ciudad Nueva (New City) microfinance institution in Machamarca, in the Pilcuyo District of the Collao Ð Puno Province. She received her first loan of 300.00 PEN two years ago, increasing her capital in order to purchase a cow for 400.00 PEN. She buys and sells cows at the markets in Pilcuyo, Acora and Ilave for a living.

With this loan of 2,000.00 PEN, which she will repay in 4 monthly installments, she will purchase 2 cows for 900.00 and 1,000.00 PEN each. Her vision is to have her own cow shed because it would bring her luck, and because selling cows is more lucrative for her than selling bulls.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase cattle (cows)

loans.name: Brigida

texts.es:
Doña Brígida cumplió 37 años de edad. Es casada y tiene dos hijos  de 19 y 07 años de edad, ella estudió quinto de secundaria, vive en la comunidad de de Machacmarca, Distrito de Pilcuyo, Provincia del Collao.

Es socia del Banco Comunal Ciudad Nueva – Machacmarca, hace un año, Brígida se dedica al negocio de compra y venta de vacuno en la ferias de Pilcuyo (Jueves) y en Ilave  (Domingo).

Con este crédito de S/. 1,200.00 Nuevos Soles, que pagará en 04 cuotas, incrementará su capital para comprar 01 toro valor de S/. 1,800.00 Nuevos Soles.

Su sueño es comprar un taxi para que su esposo trabaje y ella  seguir con el negocio aumentando más ganado vacuno para tener mejores ganancias y hacer estudiar a sus hijos para que sean profesionales.
texts.en:
Doña Brígida is 37 years old. She is married and she has two children, one 19 and one 7. She attended school until the fifth year of secondary school, and she lives in the community of Machacmarca, in the District of Pilcuyo, in the Province of Collao. She has been a member of the Community Bank called “Ciudad Nueva Machacamarca” for the past year. Brígida works buying and selling cattle in the markets in Pilcuya (on Thursdays) and in Ilave (on Sundays). With this loan of S/. 1,200.00 Nuevos Soles, that she would repay in 4 instalments, she will add to her capital in order to buy 1 bull, valued at S/. 1,800.00 Nuevos Soles. Her dream is to buy a taxi so that her husband could work, and she would continue with the business, increasing her stock of cattle in order to have better earnings so that her children can study and become professionals.

Translated from Spanish by Jessica Kaminsky, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy one bull

loans.name: Hilda Beatriz

texts.es: La señora Hilda Beatriz Hernández T. de 27 años de edad, Casada,  Quin es originaria de una comunida de Poxlajuj del departamento de Totonicapan  que para su llega a la ciudad  son cuatro kilometros  con su negocio que posee actualmente . Hace más de siete años viene trabajando de ventas de productos de consumo diario y según la demanda de los clientes ella se acercó a las oficinas de Asdir para solicitar un crédito que sera invertido en la compra de varios productos para surtir mas su tienda  la cual será invertido en tarjetas prepago de las compañías Movistar, Tigo y claro, también será invertido en compra de artículos de consumo diario para que la tienda se amplié mas, doña Hilda hace este préstamo con el único fin de que su negocio día a día se un mas grande y así  brindarle un buen servicio a sus clientes. Y que la familia pueda superar en gran manera.
texts.en:
Mrs. Hilda Beatriz Hernández T. is 27 years old, and married. She from the Proxlajuj community in the Totonicapan department. Hilda has been working in retail for seven years, and she now owns a general store. Her store is four kilometers from the nearest city. As a result of high demand, Hilda came to the Asdir offices to ask for a loan. She’ll use the money to buy prepaid phone cards from companies like Movistar, Tigo and Claro, as well as household items, to increase her business. Hilda would like a loan so that she can grow her business day by day, and provide good service to her clients. Hilda hopes that her family will get ahead.

Translated from Spanish by Sarah Bishop, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase basic goods

loans.name: Magdalena

texts.es:
Magdalena tiene 42 años D. edad, estudió quinto D. secundaria, es casada y madre D. cuatro hijos, vive en la comunidad D. Machacmarca, Distrito D. Pilcuyo, Provincia del Collao.

Ella es una D. las socias  fundadoras del Banco Comunal Ciudad Nueva – Machacmarca, desD. los quince años D. edad empezó a vender casacas aumentando su capital, a la fecha aumentó su negocio vendiendo casacas, polleras, mandiles en las ciudades D. Juliaca, Arequipa. Paralelo  a su negocio junto a su esposo compra y venD. ganado vacuno en las ferias D. Pilcuyo,  Ilave.

Con este crédito D. S/. 1,700.00 Nuevos Soles, que pagará en 04 cuotas, comprará 01 una vaca con S/. 700.00 Nuevos Soles y S/.1,000.00 Nuevos Soles invertirá para comprar mercadería como polleras (vestimenta típica D. la región) y  mandiles.

Su sueño es que sus dos hijos menores sean profesionales como son los dos mayores D. los que se siente muy orgullosa.

“Gracias a los créditos que recibo del Banco Comunal he podido aumentar mis ganancias, además no nos piden muchos documentos y es fácil D. obtener el crédito” manifestó muy contenta doña Magdalena.
texts.en:
Magdalena is 42 years old, has a high-school education and is married with four children. She lives in the community of Machacmarca. She is one of the founders of the local community bank. She started selling jackets at the age of 15 to raise money and to date she has expanded her inventory to incluD. jackets, skirts and aprons, which she sells in the cities of Juliaca and Arequipa. Along with her business, she and her husband buy and sell livestock at the Pilcuyo fair markets. With the current loan she is requesting, which she plans to repay within four months, she will purchase one cow and put the rest toward buying supplies like skirts and aprons typical to the region. Her dream is for her two youngest children to become professionals like her two oldest, of whom she's very proud.

A very content Magdalena said: "Thanks to the loans that I receive from the community bank, I have been able to increase my earnings. They also don't ask for many documents; it's easy to get the loan."

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase a cow and typical skirts and aprons of the region

loans.name: Keyling Liduvine

texts.es: Keyling es habitante del Barrio Villa Reconciliación  es una joven de 24 años, Licenciada en Administración de Empresas y labora para una Empresa de Transporte llamada Nicatransport, S.A. desempeñándose como Gestor Aduanero desde hace un año. Ella esta casada y su esposo trabaja como engrasador de Vehículos y la apoya con los gastos del hogar, tienen una bebe de 1 ½ año y su mayor sueño es poder brindarle una casa digna con los espacios definidos  y por eso que solicita su préstamo para mejoras de su vivienda, va a construir el porche. En un futuro ella quiere ser la dueña de un negocio propio ya que su papa es dueño de un taller de enderezado y pintura y ella le apoya en la administración del mismo desde hace 7 años y  ha adquirido buena experiencia en este ramo.
texts.en:
Keyling lives in the Barrio Villa Reconciliacion. She is a young woman, 24 years old, with a college degree in Business Administration, and she works for a Transportation business called Nicatransport, S.A. as a customs solicitor for a year now. She is married and her husband works as a vehicle greaser and helps out with the household expenses. They have a baby girl who is 1 and a half years old, and their greatest dream is to be able to offer her a decent house with separate defined spaces. This is why she requests a loan to improve her house, to construct the porch. In the future, she wants to own her own business because her father owns a repair shop and she has been helping him with the administration of that business for 7 years, and in the process acquired considerable experience in this field.

Translated from Spanish by Eliana Colunga, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Building a porch

loans.name: Emerita Mercedes

texts.es: Doña Emerita es una madre soltera de 34 años de edad, tiene 3 hijas mujeres las cuales están estudiando, después de la separación de su compañero ha tenido que trabajar duro para sacar adelante a sus hijas, buscando alternativas de trabajo para poder sobrevivir, comenzó alquilando un pequeño terreno que tiene y de esos ingresos  invirtió en la comercialización de productos cosméticos por encargos, apoyándose en pequeños catálogos que suministran las casas distribuidoras de cosméticos, solicita este crédito para mejorar las condiciones en la que se encuentra su vivienda por lo que su plan de inversión es la compra de Zinc y cuartones de madera para levantar un cerco en su casa, una de sus metas es incrementar su clientela para obtener mejores beneficios y seguir mejorando sus condiciones de vida.
texts.en:
Emerita is a 34 year old single mother, she has 3 daughters who are students. After separating from her husband she ha shad to work hard to help her daughters get ahead, looking for alternative work in order to survive. She began renting a small plot of land that she has and with this income she invested in selling cosmetic products by order, supporting herself with small catalogues that the cosmetic distributors supply to her. She is asking for this loan to improve the living conditions of her home, her plan is to buy zinc and wood to build a fence around her home. One of her goals is to increase her clientele in order to obtain better income and continue improving her living conditions.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Build a wall around her home

loans.name: Elena

texts.es:
Doña Elena tiene 46 años de edad, estudió tercero de secundaria es casada, madre de cinco hijos, vive en la comunidad de Machacmarca.

Socia del Banco Comunal Ciudad Nueva – Machacmarca, Distrito de Pilcuyo, Provincia del Collao – Puno, ella empezó hacer negocio desde que tuvo su pareja, a un inicio vendía ropa de segunda mano en la ciudad de Ilave, posteriormente durante cinco años se dedicó a la compra y venta de ganado vacuno en las ferias de Pilcuyo, Ilave, acumulando poco a poco su capital; hace seis años su esposo migró a la selva, Putina Punco de la Provincia de Sandia, dedicándose a la agricultura, actualmente ella lleva papa, chuño, haba, tunta (papa procesada) y comercializa en la selva Putina Punco.

Con este crédito de S/. 1,400.00 Nuevos Soles, que pagará es 04 cuotas comprará: 03 quintales de papa, 02 quintales de chuño, 05 arrobas de tunta que serán comercializados en Putina Punco – Sandia.

Su visión es hacer negocio de compra y venta de ganado vacuno en mayor escala, apoyar a sus hijos  en su educación y sean profesionales.
texts.en:
Elena is 46 years old, she completed third year of secondary school, is married and mother of five children. She lives in Machacmarca. She is a member of the Communal Bank “Nueva Machacmarca” from the Pilcuyo district, Collaro Puno region. She began her business when she married. At first she sold second-hand clothing in Ilave city, then for five years she bought and sold cattle at the Pilcuyo and Ilave markets, saving her money little by little. Six years ago her husband moved to the jungle, to Puntina Punco in Sandia province, where he farms, and today she takes potatoes, potato flour, beans, “tunta” (processed potatoes) and sells them in the Putina Punco jungle. With this loan for S/. 1,400.00 Nuevos Soles, which will be repaid in 4 payments, she will buy: 3 quintales of potatoes, 3 quintales of potato flour, 5 arrobas of processed potatoes that will be sold in Putina Punco Sandia. (Note: a quintal is 46kg and an arroba is a regional weight of approximately 11.5 kg.) Her vision is to have a business buying and selling cattle on a larger scale and support her children and their education so that they may become professionals.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy potatoes, beans, potato flour and processed potatoes.

loans.name: Pablo Absalón

texts.es: A sus 61 años de edad don Pablo Absalón tiene un pequeño negocio de venta de cereales que el mismo procesa de Maíz, Trigo, avena, cacao, etc., además vende un postre de nombre Arroz en Leche muy popular en nuestra cultura, él está casado y su esposa trabaja en costura, tienen  3 hijos ya mayores de edad los cuales trabajan independientes, Don Pablo inició su negocio hace ya  12 años después de quedarse sin empleo como trabajador de la construcción , su liquidación final fue para el inicio de la inversión de este pequeño negocio, el cual, aduce le llena mucho de satisfacción ya que ha captado una buena clientela que gustan de sus productos. Uno de sus sueños es poder darle mayor seguridad a su casa de habitación por lo que solicita este crédito para la compra de materiales de construcción y poder construir una pared trasera de su casa.
texts.en:
At 61 years of age, Pablo Absalón has a small business selling grains, such as corn, wheat, oats, cocoa, etc. that he himself processes. In addition, he sells a dessert called Arroz en Leche (Rice in Milk) that is very popular in this culture. He is married, his wife is a seamstress and they have three adult children that are working. Don Pablo started his business 12 years ago after finding himself without work in his field of construction. His severance pay was used as the initial investment in this small business, which gives him a lot of satisfaction since he has gained a solid clientele that likes his products. One of his dreams is to be able to provide greater security for his house, for which he is requesting this loan to be able to buy construction materials to build a rear wall for the house.

Translated from Spanish by Donald Allen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Construction of a rear wall for his house

loans.name: Maria Teresa

texts.es: Maria Teresa tiene 52 años de edad, vive en el Bario Villa Fraternidad, está casada, su esposo es empleado activo de una gasolinera desempeñándose como Bombero de combustible, tuvieron 4 hijos los cuales ya son mayores de edad y trabajan independiente. Maria Teresa administra una pulpería en su casa de habitación, la inició hace ya 17 años cuando dejó de laborar para un ministerio. La pulpería le ha generado ingresos para sostenerla, pero a medida que la situación económica ha golpeado los precios de consumo básico la demanda a disminuido un poco por lo que siempre ella busca alternativas para satisfacer las demandas de los clientes, y en esto doña Maria Teresa ha cautivado a sus clientes por brindarles un buen servicio. Nos comenta que quiere seguir mejorando su nivel de vida por lo que nos demanda un crédito para mejoras de su vivienda, por lo que invertirá en compra de materiales de construcción para hacer las mejoras en la fachada de su casa y su casa tenga mejor presentación.
texts.en:
Maria Teresa is 52 years old and lives in the Villa Fraternidad neighborhood. She is married and her husband is an employee at a gas station as a pump attendant. They have 4 children which are adult aged and work on their own. Maria Teresa administers a store in their house, which she started 17 years ago when she stopped working for a local ministry. The store has generated income to sustain them, but as the economic situation has impacted the prices of basic goods demand has fallen somewhat therefore she is always looking for alternatives to satisfy her client's needs and has maintained them by providing good service. She tells us that she wants to continue improving her quality of life which is why she is requesting a loan for improvements to her house. The money will be invested in the purchase of construction materials for the improvement of the facade of her house so that it has a better appearance.

Translated from Spanish by Donald Allen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Improving the facade of her house

loans.name: Albertina

texts.es: Doña Albertina tiene 45 años de edad, es soltera tiene dos hijos un varón y una mujer que ya son mayores de edad, doña Albertina trabaja como docente de la Educación  primaria en un colegio de Managua,  tiene 9 años de experiencia como maestra y presenta como un plan futuro seguirse preparando académicamente para fortalecerse como profesional de la educación en Nicaragua, Nos solicita apoyo para recibir crédito para componer la tubería del desagüe de su casa de habitación y también poder embaldosar parte del patio ya que en época de Invierno el agua acumulada pone la tierra muy difícil de transitar.
texts.en:
Doña Albertina is 45 years old. She is single and has two children, one man and one woman who are already grown up. Doña Albertina works as a teacher for primary education in a high school in Managua. She has 9 years of experience as a teacher and she has a plan for the future in order to continue preparing academically to improve herself as an educational professional in Nicaragua. She has asked us for help in getting a loan in order to repair the piping of the drains in her home and also to be able to tile part of the patio that during winter accumulates floods her floor, making it very difficult to pass.

Translated from Spanish by Jessica Kaminsky, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To change the drainage pipes and tile the patio

loans.name: Norma

texts.es:
Norma cumplió 26 años de edad, estudio quinto de secundaria, es casada y tiene 01 hijo de 04 años de edad, vive en el barrio Pilcuyo.

Hace un año es socia del Banco Comunal Ciudad Nueva, Distrito de Pilcuyo, Provincia del Collao – Puno, con su primer préstamo de S/. 500.00 Nuevos Soles compró 10 arrobas de quinua. Desde que era soltera empezó a vender ropa (mandiles, casacas) en la plaza de Ilave, desde que formó su hogar se dedica a la compra y venta de: papa, chuño, quinua compra de las ferias de Ccachi, Accasa, Pilcuyo y vende en Ilave los domingos.

Con este crédito de S/. 1,200.00 Nuevos Soles que pagará en 04 cuotas comprará: 10 arrobas de quinua, 05 arrobas de chuño, 10 arrobas de papa que serán comercializados en la plaza de Ilave.

Su sueño es construir su casa acceso a la pista e instalar un taller de mecánica automotriz juntamente con su esposo y seguir con el negocio para generar mayores ingresos para educar a su hijo.
texts.en:
Norma is 26 years old, has a high school education and is married with one 4-year-old son. She lives in the neighborhood of Pilcuyo. A year ago, she became a member of the New City Community Bank, and with her first loan she purchased 10 units of quinoa (a grain). When she was single she started selling clothing (aprons, jackets) in a local square, but now that she has formed her home she makes a living buying and selling potatoes, flour and quinoa, which she purchases at the fair markets in Ccachi, Accasa and Pilcuyo and sells in the square on Sundays. With the $425 loan she is requesting, which she plans to repay within four months, she will purchase: 10 units of quinoa, 5 units of flour and 10 units of potatoes to sell. Her dream is to build a walkway to her home and install an automotive mechanic shop together with her husband, and continue with her business to generate more income for her son's education.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase potatoes, flour and quinoa (grain)

loans.name: Linda

texts.es: Doña Linda A. tiene 56 años de edad, ella es Secretaria Comercial pero ya no labora formalmente, juntamente con su esposo el Sr. Bayardo Blas quien cuenta con una pensión de vejez, iniciaron  hace  ya cuatro años un pequeño negocio de venta de cereales, a base de Maíz, Trigo, Avena, caco, etc., este producto es de alto consumo en nuestros hogares y tiene una buena demanda, ellos solicitan un crédito para mejorar la vivienda que tienen ubicada en un Barrio pobre de Managua llamado Lomas de Guadalupe, específicamente para levantar un muro y embaldosar 21 Metros cuadrados de su propiedad y poder mejorar las condiciones de vida. Sus sueño es permanecer al lado de su esposo trabajando por una vivienda digna.
texts.en:
Linda A. is 56 years old and is a commercial secretary but isn't working formally now. Together with her husband Bayardo Blas, who has a retirement pension, four years ago she started a small business selling grains, such as corn, wheat, oats, cocoa, etc. which are heavily consumed in the region and have a high demand. They are requesting a loan to improve their house that is located in a poor neighborhood of Managua called Lomas de Guadalupe, specifically to put up a wall and tile 21 square meters of the house to improve their living conditions. Her dream is to remain by her husband's side working for a dignified home.

Translated from Spanish by Donald Allen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To put up a wall and tile the floor of her house

loans.name: Pastora

texts.es:
Pastora tiene 43 años D. edad, estudió primaria completa, es  casada y madre D. un hijo D. 11 años, ella vive en la comunidad D. Machacmarca,  Distrito D. Pilcuyo, Provincia del Collao.

DesD. el año 2006 es socia del Banco Comunal Ciudad Nueva – Machacmarca, desD. que tuvo su pareja hace 22 años empezó hacer negocio, los primeros años vendía ropa en la ciudad D. Ilave los días domingos, así fue acumulando su capital y cambió D. negocio, actualmente se dedica a la compra y venta D. ganado vacuno en las ferias D. Pilcuyo (Jueves), Acora (Sábado) y en  Ilave los (Domingos).

Con este crédito D. S/. 2,500.00 Nuevos Soles, que pagará en 04 cuotas, comprará 02 toros y los venderá en las diferentes ferias ya mencionadas.

Su meta es comprar un camión para transportar ganado vacuno, así obtendrá más ganancias y podrá educar a su único hijo hasta que sea profesional.
texts.en:
Pastora is 43 years old, completed elementary school, is married and a mother of an 11 year old son, and lives in the community of Machacmarca, Pilcuyo District, Collao Province. She has been a member of the Ciudad Nueva D. Machacmarca community bank since 2006. After marrying, 22 years ago, she started engaging in business. During the first few years she sold clothing in the city of Llave, accumulating capital in order to start a different business, and currently works selling and buying cattle in the markets of Pilcuyo (Thursdays), Acora (Saturdays) and Llave (Sundays). With this loan of 2,500 Nuevo Soles, which will be repaid in 4 installments, she will buy two bulls and will sell them in the various aforementioned markets. Her goal is to buy a truck to transport the cattle; this way she will earn more income and will be able to educate her only son through the university level.

Translated from Spanish by Donald Allen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of livestock (bulls)

loans.name: Santa Andrea

texts.es: La Señora Santa Andrea A. Álvarez de 55  años quien es originaria  del cantón Panquix municipio y departamento de Totonicapán. Acudió a las oficinas de ASDIR para poder obtener un financiamiento  para la compra de mercaderías específicamente se dedica al Comercio (tienda), el cual es un oficio que heredó de su padre quien laboró en la misma hace ya varios años. En un principio se dedicaba también al comercio en su  tienda  pequeña   ya que en estos últimos años fue creciendo su negocio  que por  lo tanto   de este crédito que solicita le servirá para comprar más mercaderías que surtirá su tienda de otros productos básicos el cual le traería muy buenas ganancias en su actividad de comercio,   con el financiamiento pretende mejorar la economía de su familia que también podrá  aumentar su capital de trabajo.
texts.en:
Santa Andrea is 55 years old and originally from Panquix, Totnicapán. She went to the offices of Kiva partner ASDIR to be able to obtain a loan to purchase specific supplies for her store, which she inherited from her father after he labored there for many years. She started out working in the small shop and in these past few years it has been growing, which is the reason she is requesting this loan to purchase more supplies that will stock her store with more everyday products. She has been making good earnings with her work, and with the loan she expects to improve her family's finances and also be able to increase her working capital.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase supplies for store

loans.name: Ilda

texts.es:
Doña Ilda cumplió 39 años de edad, estudió primaria completa, es casada y tiene tres hijos que fluctúan entre los 08, 07 y 04 años de edad, vive en la Comunidad de Machacmarca.

Con visión de salir adelante ella decidió integrar el Banco Comunal Ciudad Nueva del Distrito de Pilcuyo, Provincia del Collao – Puno. Con su primer crédito de S/. 300.00 Nuevos Soles compró 02 ovinos, ella se dedica al negocio de compra y venta de ganado vacuno, ovino, porcino, comprando los días sábados en la feria de Acora y los días jueves vende en la feria de Pilcuyo, dedicándose a éste negocio hace 14 años desde que vive con su esposo, siempre le gustó hacer negocio desde los 17 años de edad vendía ropa en el mercado de Ilave.

Con este crédito de S/. 1,600.00 Nuevos Soles que pagará en 04 cuotas tiene presupuestado comprar 01 vacuno, 02 porcinos, 01 ovino que serán comercializados en la feria de Pilcuyo.

Su mayor sueño es comprar una casa en la ciudad de Ilave y seguir trabajando con su negocio para obtener más ganancias y educar a sus hijos para que sean profesionales.
texts.en:
Doña Ilda is 39 years old and married with three children who are 4, 7, and 8 years old. She completed primary school, and currently lives in the community of Machacmarca. With a vision to get ahead in life, she decided to join the Ciudad Nueva Communal Bank (a group loan) in the Pilcuyo District of Collao Province, Puno. With her first loan of 300 soles (slightly more than US $100) she bought two sheep. Ilda buys and sells cows, sheep, and pigs; she buys them on Saturdays in the Acora market and sells them on Thursdays in the Pilcuyo market. She has been in this business since she began living with her husband many years ago. She has always enjoyed being a businesswoman, ever since she was 17 and sold clothing in the Ilave market. With this loan of 1,600 nuevo soles (about US $540), which she will repay in 4 installments, Ilda plans to buy a cow, two pigs, and one sheep to resell in the Pilcuyo market. Her greatest dream is to buy a house in the city of Ilave, continue working with her business to earn more, and educate her children so they can grow up to be professionals.

Translated from Spanish by Cynthia McMurry, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy livestock

loans.name: Martina

texts.es:
Martina tiene 58 años D. edad estudió hasta segundo año D. primaria, es casada, madre D. un hijo y vive en la comunidad D. Machacmarca.

Hace 02 años es socia del Banco Comunal Ciudad Nueva, Machacmarca, Distrito  D. Pilcuyo, Provincia del Collao , el primer crédito que obtuvo D. S/. 300.00 Nuevos Soles incrementó al capital que ella tenía y compró 01 vacuno con S/. 800.00 Nuevos Soles desD. que era soltera, siempre le gustó hacer negocio, empezó vendiendo gaseosas, desD. que tuvo su pareja empezó con el negocio D. compra y venta D. ganado vacuno en las ferias D. Pilcuyo, Acora, Ilave, López, Huapaca San Miguel.

Con este crédito D. S/. 2,500.00 Nuevos Soles, que pagará en 04 cuotas comprará 02 toros uno con S/. 1,600.00 Nuevos Soles y el otro con S/. 1,200.00 Nuevos Soles, los cuales serán comercializados en las ferias ya mencionadas.

Su visión es ampliar su cobertizo para  albergar más ganado vacuno.
texts.en:
Martina is 58 years old, studied until the second graD., is married and the mother of one son and lives in the Machacmarca community. She has been a member of the Ciudad Nueva community bank for two years, which is loacated in the city of Machacmarca, Pilcuyo District, Collao Province. The first loan that she obtained, of 300 Nuevo Soles, was used to increase her capital to purchase one bull costing 800 Nuevo Soles. Since she was single she has liked engaging in business. She started selling sodas and after marrying she started her business of buying and selling cattle in markets of Pilcuyo, Acora, Llave, López, Huapaca, and San Miguel. With this loan of 2,500 Nuevo Soles, which will be repaid in 4 payments, she will buy 2 bulls, one costing 1,600 Nuevo Soles and the other 1,200 Nuevo Soles, which will be sold in the aforementioned markets. Her vision is to enlarge her shed to store more cattle.

Translated from Spanish by Donald Allen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of cattle

loans.name: Gurgina

texts.es:
Gurgina  cumplió 43 años de edad, estudió hasta tercero de primaria, casada y tiene tres hijos, vive en la comunidad de Machacmarca.

Es socia fundadora del Banco Comunal Ciudad Nueva de la comunidad de Machacmarca, Distrito de Pilcuyo, Provincia del Collao,  a los 19 años de edad tuvo su pareja desde entonces se dedica a la compra y venta de ganado vacuno en las ferias de  Pilcuyo, Acora e Ilave, con su primer crédito de S/. 300.00 Nuevos Soles compró 02 corderos para su posterior venta.

Con este crédito de S/. 2,500.00 Nuevos Soles, el cual pagará en 04 cuotas, tiene previsto comprar 02 toros, cada vacuno le costará un promedio de S/. 1,200.00 Nuevos Soles.

Su visión es comprar una casa en la ciudad de Ilave, tener un establo para 10 cabezas de ganado vacuno para engorde y que su hijo menor estudie ya que los dos mayores ya tienen su familia.
texts.en:
Gurgina is 43 years old, she completed third grade in primary school, is married and has three children. She lives in Machacmarca. She is a member of the Communal Bank “Ciudad Nueva” in Machacmarca, Pilcuyo district, Collao state. At 19 years old she married and since then has been buying and selling cattle in the Pilcuyo, Acora and Ilave markets. With her first loan for S/. 300.00 Nuevos Soles she bought 2 lambs for future sale. With this loan for S/. 2,500.00 Nuevos Soles, which will be repaid in 4 payments, she will buy 2 bulls, each will cost an average of S/. 1,200.00 Nuevos Soles. Her vision is to buy a house in Ilave city, have a stable for 10 head of cattle to raise, and that her youngest son study as the two older children now have their own families.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy cattle

loans.name: Sonia Nelly

texts.es:
Sonia tiene 50 años D. edad, estudió cuarto D. secundaria, es casada, madre D. cuatro hijos, vive en la comunidad D. Machacmarca, Distrito D. Pilcuyo, Provincia del Collao.

Es socia del Banco Comunal Ciudad Nueva – Machacmarca, desD. el año 2007, con su primer crédito D. S/. 300.00 Nuevos Soles compró 04 ovinos, ella desD. los quince años empezó a vender ropa (chompas, pantalones, mandiles), que llevaba  a las ferias D.  Ilave, Desaguadero, Yunguyo, Acora, Mazocruz, a los 17 años formó su familia y durante tres años seguía con el negocio, posteriormente cambió D. negocio a la compra y venta D. ganado vacuno, ovino. Hasta la fecha compra D. las ferias D. Ilave, Juli y venD. en Pilcuyo los jueves y algunas veces también venD. chuño, papa en la ciudad D. Juliaca.   

Con este crédito D. S/. 1,500.00 Nuevos Soles que pagará en 03 cuotas, comprará 01 toro con S/. 1,200.00, 02 ovinos D. raza cada uno a S/.150.00  para su posterior venta en la feria D. Pilcuyo.

Su mayor sueño es que sus dos hijos menores sean profesionales y los dos mayores que ya tienen su familia incrementen su negocio, también le gustaría comprar un taxi para viajar con su familia.
texts.en:
Sonia is 50 years old, studied until her fourth year of secondary school, is married and the mother of four children and lives in the community of Machacmarca, Pilcuyo District, Collao Province. She has been a member of the Ciudad Nueva community bank in Machacmarca since 2007. With her first loan of 300 Nuevo Soles she bought 4 sheep. When she was fifteen years old she started selling clothing (sweaters, pants, aprons), that she took to the markets of Llave, Desaguader, Yunguyo, Acora, and Mazocruz. At 17, she started her family and for three years continued with the business. Later she changed businesses and started buying and selling cattle and sheep. Currently she buys in the markets of Llave, Juli and sells in Pilcuyo on Thursdays and sometimes also sells chuño, a potato product, in the city of Juliaca. With this loan of 1,500 Nuevos Soles , which will be repaid in 3 months, she will buy one bull costing 1,200 Nuevos Soles and two sheep costing 150 Nuevos Soles each to be sold in the Pilcuyo market. Her biggest dream is that her two youngest children become professionals and that the two oldest that already have their own families increase their businesses and would also like to buy a car to travel with her family.

Translated from Spanish by Donald Allen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of livestock (sheep)

loans.name: Abejitas (The Little Bees) Group

texts.es:
En la zona de Villa Exaltación  de la ciudad de El Alto se encuentra ubicado el centro focal del mismo nombre, a este pertenece la asociación “Abejitas” 
Un grupo formado por 10 mujeres, grupo muy simpático que  junto  a su asesora de créditos, trabajan con Pro-Mujer con mucho entusiasmo para mejorar en sus negocios.
La mayoría de ellas son casadas y con hijos de distintas edades, nos cuentan  que los gastos diarios que tienen en sus hogares crecen cada vez mas y los ingresos que tienen ya no son suficientes para cubrir necesidades mínimas de sus hogares.
Este grupo se dedica principalmente a la elaboración de alimentos, preparan variedad de pastelitos, empanadas  y otras exquisiteces en el área de la repostería, también elaboran almuerzos y otros platillos en restaurantes ubicados  en la  ciudad de El Alto y en la localidad de Desaguadero, Necesitan mayor capital para la compra de insumos
texts.en:
In the zone Villa Exaltación in the city of El Alto, you will find a central location with this same name. To this belongs the group “Abejitas” (“The little bees”), a group made up of 10 women, a very kind group who together with their loan officer, work with Pro-Mujer with lots of enthusiasm to improve their businesses. The majority of them are married with children of different ages. They have realized that the daily expenses that they have in their homes grow each day more, and the incomes that they have already are not sufficient to cover the minimal necessities of their homes. This group is primarily dedicated to food preparation. They make a variety of sweets, empanadas, and other exquisite bits of confectionary. They also make lunches and other plates in the restaurants located in the city of El Alto and in the area of Desaguadero. They need more capitol in order to buy ingredients.

Translated from Spanish by Jessica Kaminsky, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: They need funds to purchase ingredients

loans.name: Canaverales Group

texts.en:
It was 10 a.m. this morning while I was going about Kiva Fellow business, when I got a call from the Friendship Bridge office - there was a group meeting in an hour and a half and two bus journeys away, if I was available T. go and meet with them? Sometimes travelling T. these remote villages can be a tedious part of the job of a Fellow, but Santa Clara is one of my favourite villages that I have visited, and I don't hesitate T. agree T. go.

After the long but easy journey there, I meet with the Cañaverales group on the patio next T. the kitchen of a senior member just off one of the main streets of Santa Clara. The bright floral-patterned blouses and skirts of the women nearly blind one with their brilliance and the space is abuzz with their happy conversation and laughter. Children of all ages dart back and forth between the women, being so affectionate with each that it's difficult T. tell which woman is a particular child's mother. Despite the commotion, it takes only a few moments before I can quiet everyone so I can ask them a few questions.

Despite the fact that Santa Clara is most famous for basket-making (as proudly displayed on the sign that welcomed me inT. the town), the common thread of the group is that all 17 women tend small farms, raising either chickens or pigs or both. Fourteen of them also supplement their income with embroidery while three others put their sewing skills T. work. One of the women also buys and sells clothing. The group's president, Carmen Rosa, who has a farm of 50 chickens and embroiders as well, tells me that none of the women has T. leave the town T. sell their products as Santa Clara is the commercial hub for the surrounding area.

These women are no strangers T. micro-credit. They already know the life-changing potential of this money; for some of them, this will be their eighth loan. Friendship Bridge is implementing a new repayment scheme for experienced groups such as this one. The Cañaverales will pay back this loan in 9 months instead of the normal 13, and they're quite confident of their ability T. meet this more demanding schedule.

T. my question about the benefits this loan may bring, one of the older women, Catalina, tells me that she just recently had all her chickens and her pig slaughtered. With the credit that she's applying for now, she hopes T. replenish her stocks and this time she'll try T. raise two pigs. Another younger woman, Florinda, stands up and says that with the profit she makes with her embroidery design, her ever-growing young children will finally be able T. have clothes that fit them for school.

My last question of the session: what are your dreams? The answer is never very different from group T. group, or even person T. person, anywhere across the world. All the women want their children T. have a better life with more opportunities than they have had. Resoundingly and almost in one voice, they hope that their children can achieve a level of education that was unavailable T. them. The extra money from micro-credit loans like the ones provided by Kiva and Friendship Bridge will help ensure that this will happen.

loans.use: invest in buying more animals to raise

loans.name: 23 De Marzo (23Rd Of March) Group

texts.es:
En la ciudad de El Alto se encuentra el centro focal de Villa Exaltación  a éste pertenece, la asociación “ 23 de marzo ”, integrada 17 mujeres ansiosas de progresar en sus pequeños negocios.
La mayoría en el grupo son casadas y afirman que necesitan ayudar a sus parejas en la economía del hogar, ya que tienen un promedio de 4 niños , muchas de ellas por distintos motivos, se separaron de su pareja y tuvieron  que hacerse cargo de su familia por lo que necesitan mayores recursos para  subsistir.
La actividad principal en la asociación “23 de marzo” es la costura de edredones, sabanas y también la confección de camisas, ropa deportiva y otros, estas prendas las comercializan al  Perú, las venden al por mayor. Ellas precisan capital para comprar materia prima en mayor cantidad de ésta manera aumentar su producción y generar mayores ganancias para el bien de sus familias.
texts.en:
In the city of El Alto you will find the location of Villa Exaltación. To this area belongs the association “23 de Marzo” (“The 23rd of March”). It is made up of 17 women anxious to improve their tiny businesses. Most of the women in the group are married and they assert that it is necessary to help their spouses with the household expenses. They currently have an average of 4 children each. Some of them, for different reasons, have separated from their spouses and they have to bear the entire load of the family. Because of this they need more resources to make a living. The primary activity in the association 23 de Marzo is making blankets, sheets, and also shirts, sports clothing, and more. These articles are sold in Perú, where they sell for more. They need capitol in order to buy more materials in larger quantities, and by this manner increase their production and generate higher earnings for the betterment of their families.

Translated from Spanish by Jessica Kaminsky, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Funds to buy larger quantities of materials

loans.name: Trébol Group

texts.es:
El grupo Trébol esta formado por 13 socias que trabajan junto a la  familia de Pro-Mujer en el centro focal de Villa Tejada ubicada en  la ciudad de el Alto. 
La asociación Trébol, se dedican a la venta de verduras y también a la elaboración y venta de comida,  para la producción de almuerzos necesitan proveerse de alimentos frescos por lo que muy temprano van a las ferias para abastecerse de todo lo necesario. Necesitan mayor capital para realizar mejoras en sus  ambientes de  trabajo, para ofrecer comodidad a sus clientes, con la única finalidad de incrementar sus ventas y ganancias para  mejorar el estilo de vida para sus hijos.
texts.en:
The group Trébol is formed by 13 female women who work together with Pro-Mujer in the center of Villa Tejada, located in the city of Alto. The group Trébol is dedicated to the sales of vegetable and also the creation and sales of food. For making the lunches, they need provide fresh foods, for which they go very early to the markets to acquire everything necessary. They need greater capital to do a better job in their field of work, to offer more convenience to their clients, and to ultimately increase their sales and earnings in order to improve their childrens' lifestyles.

Translated from Spanish by Jay Osborne, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: more capital to work with

loans.name: Khim

texts.en:
Khim S. E. is 28 years old and works growing yams on her plot of farmland in Kampong Cham, Cambodia. She is sometimes employed to take care of other villagers' farms to earn a living. On average, she makes around US$3.20 each day. Her husband, Mea Chet, is a horse-cart driver and is able to make US$4.20 per day. He just started driving a horse cart this year, and before, he helped his wife growing yams.  
Currently, Khim is asking for a loan from Kiva via Credit, the local partner, of US$400 to purchase another horse. The extra horse will be hired for extra profits. She told a loan officer that on average she spends around US$40 every month on food, US$2 on utilities, US$35 on her children's education and US$5 on transportation. She has four children, one of whom is a student, and three others are too young to attend school. In the future, she wants all the children to get to a higher class in order to get a good job. If she has enough money she will build a better house for her family members.

loans.use: To purchase another horse for hiring.

loans.name: Meng

texts.en: Meng S., 46, is married and lives with five of her six children in Kampong Cham Province, Cambodia. She works growing rice, but her farm is just enough for her family members annually. She told a loan officer that some years she earns less output because she has difficulties with water. Her husband, Ith Bik, 47, makes around US$2.60 each day from construction building houses, and he acts as a cow dealer as well. Three of their children are students and two others are employed as a construction worker and a garment factory worker. Meng is requesting a loan of US$300 for her husband to purchase cows for sale. This will help double the family income. There are no plans for the business in the future, yet she wants all the children to attend the higher class in order to get a good job in the future. She told a loan officer that on average she spends around US$50 each month on food, US$2 on utilities, US$10 on children's education and US$15 on transportation.

loans.use: To purchase cow for sale.

loans.name: Mujeres Del 2000 Group

texts.es: La asociación “mujeres del 2000” trabaja hace mas de siete años en el centro focal de Villa tejada, grupo formado por 15 mujeres, la mayoría de ellas casadas y con un promedio de cinco hijos, afirman que los gastos diarios que tienen en sus hogares aumentan cada día mas, por lo que deben buscar otras fuentes de ingreso. Ellas realizan diferentes actividades algunas se dedican a la costura,  otras tienen sus tiendas de barrio, también se dedican al tejido a mano de chompas, mantillas y ponchos, entre otros, trabajos que los realizan en lana y en hilo, que una vez elaborados los venden al por mayor. Ellas quieren crédito para aumentar su producción y poder llevar sus productos al interior del país, de esta manera generar mayores ganancias.
texts.en:
The group "Mujeres del 2000" ("Women of 2000") has been working for seven years in the town's textile trade mostly. It is a group formed by fifteen women, the majority of them married and with an average of five children, and they say that the daily expenses that they have for their home increase more each day, which is why they must search for other sources of income. They do different activities. Some are dedicated to sewing, others have neighborhood stores, and some are dedicated to weaving by hand sweaters, baby clothes, and blankets, among other things, which are works that they create with wool and yarn and then sell in bulk. They want a loan to increase their production and to be able to carry their products to the interior of the country, and in this manner they can generate more earnings.

Translated from Spanish by Jay Osborne, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase their production and to be able to deliver their products to the interior of their country.

loans.name: Kin

texts.en: Kin T. is 53 years old and has worked raising animals on her plot of land since 1983. On average, she makes US$2 each day. Her husband is an old farmer growing cucumbers and is able to make US$2 each day as well. This couple together has one child, who works at a garment factory. Farming is making less profit to support the family, so Kin has decided to take out a loan of US$1000 to build a big stand selling rice and food in front of a garment factory. This will allow her family to earn much more than farming and raising animals.

loans.use: To build a big stand selling rice and food in front of a garment factory.

loans.name: Sor

texts.en:
Mr. Sor L. S. is 30 years old and is a father of three children who are too young to attend school. He and his wife work growing rice on their piece of farmland, and the outputs twice a year contribute $4 each day.

In Cambodia, people grow rice twice a year, which is called "rainy season rice" and "dry season rice," but in some areas, people can grow rice up to three times per year. In order to increase his family's income, Mr. Sor L. S. would like to request a loan from Kiva via CREDIT to purchase fertilizer for his crops, buy rice crops from growers to keep in stock, and resell when the price is increasing. Moreover, he will use the leftovers of the loan to purchase a motorbike to operate a motor-taxi when he is free from his farming work. (His wife is pictured because Mr. Sor L. S. is unavailable).

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer for his crops

loans.name: Oem

texts.en: Oem S., age 28, is a true entrepreneur and has a business selling vegetables at an open air market. She usually earns around US$1.50 each day. Her husband, Sok Yun, is a farmer and makes US$2 each day. This couple together has three children, one of whom is a student and others are too young to attend school. Oem is requesting a loan of US$500 to increase the number of vegetables for sale and also to start selling chicken.

loans.use: To increase the number of vegetables for sale and also to start selling chicken.

loans.name: Warmin Sartawipa Group

texts.es:
La fabricación y venta de ladrillos es la actividad principal de la asociación Warmin Sartawipa, traducido al español quiere decir Los pasos de la Mujer, grupo formado por once mujeres, trabajan junto a Pro-Mujer hace 10 años en el centro focal de Villa Tejada.
Casi todas casadas junto con sus esposos trabajan para salir adelante por el bien de sus hijos,  Luego de la fabricar los ladrillos los venden a pedido en las distintas zonas de la ciudad de El Alto. En ocasiones realizan sus ventas a crédito por lo que necesitan capital para comprar materia prima que les perM. entregar pedidos a los clientes. Solo trabajan con el objetivo de mejorar económicamente para brindar bienestar a sus familias
texts.en:
The production and sales of bricks is the main activity of the group Warmin Sartawipa, which when translated to Spanish means "Los Pasos de la Mujer." The group is formed by eleven women who have worked in the center of Villa Tejada with Pro-Mujer for ten years. Almost all the women are married and with their husbands they work to make progress for the good of their children. After making the bricks, they sell them by taking orders from various regions of the city of El Alto. On occasion they make sales based on credit, which is why they need capital to buy raw materials so they can fill the orders of their clients. They only work with the objective of improving economically to offer well-being to their families.

Translated from Spanish by Jay Osborne, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Capital to buy raw materials.

loans.name: Long

texts.en: Long N., 29, is a housewife cooking food and looking after the children. Her husband works making jars to sell around the village. Normally, he makes US$4.3 of profit each day. To make more jars, Mrs. Long has requested a loan of US$200 to purchase more cement. (Long's husband is pictured at his home).

loans.use: To purchase more cement

loans.name: Khen

texts.en: Khen K., 28, is married and lives with her three children in the Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. Since 2001, she has been running a grocery stand to earn a living and is able to make a profit of $2.50 a day. Her husband, Nam Roth, is a traditional theater actor, and he typically makes a profit of $42.50 in a week. Currently, Khen is requesting a loan of $600 to purchase a motorbike for her husband to operate a motor-taxi. This will help bring in a larger profit to the family each week.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for her husband to operate a motor-taxi.

loans.name: Yen

texts.en: Yen N., 28, works growing vegetables in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. Her farm is just enough to support her family members. Her husband, Nhem Nhoeun, 30, is a construction worker building houses. On average, he makes US$5 each day. Yen wants to have profit from her farm, so she decided to take out a loan of US$400 to purchase fertilizers and more seeds to grow.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers and more seeds to grow.

loans.name: Ing

texts.en:
Mrs. Ing S., 36 years old, is a widow and lives with children and her younger sister and brother. She sells rice and various kinds of Khmer food at a stand near her town. Each day she makes around 10 dollars a day of gross income.

Mrs. Ing S. is currently facing financial difficulties and has recently requested a loan from KIVA to pay for her rent expenses and purchase more materials to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more utensils and other equipments to expand her business

loans.name: Un

texts.en: Un H. who is 45 years old, is a housewife who looks after her children and cooks food for her family members. Her husband, Ly Eang, 49 years old, is a taxi driver around the market in the village and normally makes around US$3.7. Before, he used to earn more but currently because of the high inflation he makes less profits. “Cambodia's inflation hit a record high of 22 percent in July” said a government minister. Every thing has skyrocketed in price so poor people can not afford spend money. The high price of gas has forced the taxi driver out of business. Mrs. Un is requesting a loan from Kiva of US$500 to purchase a motorbike for her husband to run a taxi.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for her husband to run a moto taxi.

loans.name: Heng

texts.en: Heng S., 26 years old, is married and lives with one of her children in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. Since 2000, she has worked planting vegetables and is able to make 2 US dollars per day. Her husband, Un Chek, is a motor-taxi driver and makes on average $3.70 each day. In Cambodia right now, it is hard to survive, especially for poor entrepreneurs who are trying to start a business. The high price of gas is putting many motor-taxi drivers out of business. Still, her husband works in the motor-taxi business because it is hard to find a higher paying job with a better salary as someone without a good education. Heng is requesting a loan of $500 to purchase a motorbike for her husband to start his own motor-taxi business.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for her husband to run a motor-taxi.

loans.name: Khem

texts.en: Khem P., age 46, is a true entrepreneur and has a business selling groceries out of her home. She makes $4 a day. Her sister, Horn Thon, is 29 years old, and is a construction worker who builds houses. She typically earns $3 a day in order to support her family. Khem is requesting a loan of $1000 to purchase more groceries for her stand. (Khem is pictured with her sister at her home)

loans.use: To purchase more groceries to sell

loans.name: Im

texts.en:
Mrs. Im P. is 40 years old and works selling a variety of grocery items to the people in her community. She generally makes up to $50 each day of gross income. She is married and has two children, one of who is enrolled in school and the other who helps her work day to day. Her husband works as a construction foreman, however his work depends on when he is needed.
Mrs. Im P. would like to increase her capital by asking for a loan to purchase more grocery products to supply her inventory. She would like to meet her growing customers' demands and needs this loan to do so.

loans.use: To buy more grocery items to expand her business.

loans.name: Chea

texts.en: Mrs. Chea T., 50, is married and has started a business since 1979 buying recycled items from different locations in her town and reselling them to the recycling plant for a profit, each day making about $2.30 of net income. Her husband has worked as a farmer growing rice and feeding cows since 1979 as well. She has seven children. One is a student, three others are employed by a garment factory, and the other three are married and live outside the family's home. Mrs. Chea T. and her husband would like to purchase two more cows to help with their farming work. Cows can greatly help with plowing and carrying heavy items.

loans.use: To buy two cows to help her farming work.

loans.name: Ouk

texts.en:
Ouk M. is 41 years old and lives in Phnom Penh, Cambodia. She has a business as a tailor from her home to earn a living and is able to make around $3 of profit per day. Her husband, Duch Dem, 44, is a construction worker building a house. On average, he makes $2 a day. This couple has two children and both of them are employed. Mrs Ouk is asking a loan of US$300 to purchase a water pump to irrigate her farm. She needs to buy a water pump because of decreased rain over the past few years.

CREDIT MFI is an independent Cambodian faith-based organization. It aims to empower the economically active poor and small entrepreneurs by providing inclusive financial services.

loans.use: To purchase a water pump to irrigate her farm.

loans.name: Horn

texts.en:
Mr. Horn H., 50, is a construction worker who lives in Orchar Commune, Battambang Province. He can build Khmer style houses and earns approximately US$3.75 per day. Sometimes he is away from home for his construction work.

His wife, Mrs. Hun Phoeun, stays home to care for the children and cook food for the family. Horn has six children, two of whom are married. 

To increase the family's income, Horn wants to create a business for his wife, and requests a loan of US$ 600 to use as capital to purchase vegetables and resell them in the market. He plans to use the remainder of the loan purchase piglets to raise and also pig food.

loans.use: To use as capital to purchase vegetables and resell them in the market

loans.name: Touch

texts.en: Mrs. Touch B., 57, is married and lives with her husband in a part of Siem Reap province, which is an attractive tourist site in Cambodia. She and her husband work making and selling a variety of desserts to the people in her community and they collectively earn around $9/day of income. Mrs. Touch B. has five children. Her single son is employed by a construction company. Her other two daughters work at a local restaurant, and the rest of her children are married and live outside the family home. Mrs.Touch B. would like to request a loan from KIVA to expand her business and purchase more utensils and some other equipment in order to meet her growing customer demands.

loans.use: To buy more utensils for her food business

loans.name: Khiev

texts.en:
Khiev S., age 30, has a business catching fish from the river and selling her catch to the market. She is able to earn around US$2 of profit per day. Her husband is a construction worker. On average, he makes US$4 a day. This couple has two children, one of whom is a student. Mrs. Khiev would like a loan from Kiva of US$400 to breed animals in order to double her income to support the family.

CREDIT MFI is an independent Cambodian faith-based organization. It aims to empower the economically active poor and small entrepreneurs by providing inclusive financial services.

loans.use: To breed the animal for extra profit.

loans.name: Rous

texts.en:
Rous S. is a 61 year old woman living in Penh, Cambodia. She is a widow and sells Khmer cake from her home to earn a living and is able to make $6 per day. She has two children, one works at garment factory while the other sells fruit at a market. Mrs. Rous would like a loan from Kiva to purchase a motorbike for her son’s commute to work. This will save her son money that would be spent on taxi fare bringing fruit to and from the market.

CREDIT MFI is an independent Cambodian faith-based organization. It aims to empower the economically active poor and small entrepreneurs by providing inclusive financial services.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for her son's commute to work.

loans.name: Chhung

texts.en: Mrs. Chhung N. is married with three children and works with her husband on their piece of farmland growing rice and various kinds of vegetables. She and her husband can make collectively about $5 each day from selling their produce to the people in the market. In order to reduce his expenses, this couple would like to request a loan to purchase a hand tractor to assist them in plowing. With the extra revenue from the tractor this would give his family a sufficient standard of living.

loans.use: To purchase a tractor to assist in plowing her rice field.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mrs. Mary L., 25 years old, is currently a housewife who stays home to care for children and cook for her husband. Her husband has a car that he drives as a taxi, earning approximately US $6.00 per day. They live in Ratanak Commune in the Battambang Province.

To increase her family's income, Mary wants to work outside of their home. She wants to run a business of selling clothes by going to customers' homes. Mary is requesting a loan of US$ 600 to use as capital to purchase used clothes to sell.

loans.use: To purchase used clothing to resell

loans.name: Sok

texts.en:
Sok S., aged 35, is a true entrepreneur and has had a business selling sweet radishes since 2000 and makes $5 of profit per day. Her husband, Hong Hai, works picking radishes for his wife to sell. Cambodian people like radishes and normally they serve it with rice. Mrs. Sok would like to borrow from Kiva US$700 to purchase a motorbike to transport radishes to the market. This will reduce the cost that she spends every day on a motor-taxi.

CREDIT MFI is an independent Cambodian faith-based organization. It aims to empower the economically active poor and small entrepreneurs by providing inclusive financial services.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike to transport radishes to the market.

loans.name: Larch

texts.en:
Larch T., who is 53 years old, is married and sells sugar cane juice from her home to earn a living. Larch is able to make $6 of income per day. Her husband, Sang Chorn, rents rooms from his home to workers in the area. On average, he makes $2 of profit per day. This couple has four children, one of whom is a student and two others are employed as garment workers. Mrs. Larch would like to loan from Kiva to build more rooms to rent out for extra profit. 

CREDIT MFI is an independent Cambodian faith-based organization. It aims to empower the economically active poor and small entrepreneurs by providing inclusive financial services.

loans.use: Mrs. Larch would like to loan from Kiva to build more rooms to rent out for extra profit.

loans.name: Seng

texts.en:
Seng S. is 33 and works as a carpenter. He lives with his wife in Siem Reap. She earns around US$5 each day selling groceries to support their family. Their three children are currently students. Mr. Seng is requesting a loan from Kiva to purchase more wood for his carpentry as well as move towards his wife's future plan to expand her grocery store.

CREDIT MFI is an independent Cambodian faith-based organization. It aims to empower the economically active poor and small entrepreneurs by providing inclusive financial services.

loans.use: To purchase more wood for his carpentry.

loans.name: Nhen

texts.en:
Nhen K., 51, is married and lives with her three children in Siem Reap, Cambodia. Since 2005, she has been selling porridge from her home to earn a living and is able to make US$2.50 of profit each day. She is aided by her child who works as a chef and maintenance worker. Her husband, Chab Sat, is a construction worker and make US$3 per day. Mrs. Nhen is requesting a loan from Kiva to purchase a motorbike for her husband to run a motor-taxi for extra profit. (Chab is pictured because his wife was not available)

CREDIT MFI is an independent Cambodian faith-based organization. It aims to empower the economically active poor and small entrepreneurs by providing inclusive financial services.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for her husband to run a motor-taxi for extra profit.

loans.name: Um

texts.en:
Mrs. Um R., 51 years old, is a mother of seven and lives in Siem Reap province, Cambodia. She and her husband are farmers. They grow rice on their field, making one dollar per day collectively. Lately, the inflation rate has gone out control, so one dollar is barely enough to cover their family's expenses. Mrs Um R. and her husband seek another business that would enable them to lift up their living condition. Recently, this couple had made a decision to ask for a loan from KIVA to purchase a motor-bike for her husband to operate a motor-taxi business called "Motor Dub".

In Cambodia, there are not many transportation options besides Motor-taxi, Cyclo, Tuk-Tuk and a taxi, so Motor-taxi is a very favorable business. People prefer motor-taxis to taxis because they are easier and cheaper to ride. (Mrs Um R.’s husband is pictured because Mrs. Um R. was not available).

loans.use: To buy a motor-bike for her husband to operate a motor-taxi

loans.name: Ou

texts.en:
Ou S., 42, is a true entrepreneur and works with her husband, Huy Davroeun, 47, selling used clothes at the market to earn around $30 in revenue per day. This couple live in Siem Reap with one child. Every month she needs to spend around $75 on food and $100 on her child's education. To meet her customer's demands, she is requesting a loan from Kiva via Credit, the local partner, to add clothes to her inventory.

CREDIT MFI is an independent Cambodian faith-based organization. It aims to empower the economically active poor and small entrepreneurs by providing inclusive financial services.

loans.use: To add to her clothes inventory.

loans.name: Khen

texts.en:
Mr. Khen Y., 52, lives in Orchar Commune in the Battambang Province with his wife, Mrs. Kimchhean Chhun, 48. He has been working as a chief construction worker since 1998 and currently earns around US $7.00 per day. His wife stays home to care for children and cook food for the family. They have four children, one of whom is married. The others live in the family home and help support the family. One sells groceries and another one is a car repairer who earns around US $1.50 per day.

In order to increase the family's income, Khen wants his wife to be able to have a business selling porridge from their house. Khen would like to request a loan to purchase ingredients for making porridge and to decorate his house for selling porridge.

loans.use: To purchase ingredients for making porridge and to decorate his house for selling porridge

loans.name: Zubaida

texts.en: Zubaida baji A. D. is married with five children, and lives in the city of Kasur, Pakistan. Kasur is famous for its sweetmeat and decorative embroidery. She has been living in this city for the last 11 years. None of her children go to school. Her husband is a buffalo milk vendor and has been in this profession for the last 20 years.
