He currently has two buffalos at his house. Zubaida baji prefers to do house work and take care of her family. She is applying for a loan of $525 to buy another buffalo to expand her husband's dairy business.

loans.use: To buy a buffalo to expand her husband's dairy business

loans.name: Lang

texts.en:
Mrs. Lang V., is married with five children and works as a rice farmer earning only $1 each day. Her husband is a middleman buying cow to breed for only a short period then resell them for a profit. This daily business activity earns him around $3 each day. Meanwhile, one of her children is employed by a garment factory and her other two sons work at a construction site, making collectively $6 a day. Cow selling is a profitable and better business for Mrs. Lang V.'s family. She and her husband would like to purchase more cows from the breeders to increase her daily income. But they still need more capital to help them.

( Her husband is pictured because Mrs. Lang V. is not available).

loans.use: To purchase more cows from the breeder to increase more income.

loans.name: Cheb

texts.en:
This is the second time Mr. Cheb S., 29, is requesting a loan in order to improve his living conditions. His wife, Mrs. Buoy Koeurn, is a housewife who cooks delicious food for her household. The couple has three children, two of whom are enrolled in school. The family lives in Pongro Village in Kampong Cham Province

He is a potato farmer. Since his field has been covered by grass, he needs to chop the grass out in order to clear the land for growing more potatoes. Mr. Cheb S. has decided to hire laborers to do this work and is requesting a loan to help pay for their services.

loans.use: To hire laborers to chop the grass out of the field in order to grow a larger potato crop.

loans.name: Kao

texts.en:
Kao M., 52 years old, makes $2 each day working in the rice field with her husband. Kao's business has surrived recent bad weather and economic inflation. Mrs. Kao would like a loan to purchase a grinding mill buy and livestock to increase her profit.

CREDIT MFI is an independent Cambodian faith-based organization. It aims to empower the economically active poor and small entrepreneurs by providing inclusive financial services.

loans.use: To purchase a grinding mill and raise animal for extra profit.

loans.name: Sek

texts.en: Mr. Sek P., 51, lives in Russei Chuor Village in the Kampong Cham Province. He and his wife, Mrs. Uk Tep, grow potatoes in a field located next to their house. The couple have three children who all help their parents in  the field. Since this business is going well, he has decided to ask for a loan to buy more potato seeds to cultivate a larger crop.

loans.use: To buy more potato seeds to cultivate.

loans.name: Shabana

texts.en: Shabana baji is married with four daughters and lives in Kasur, Pakistan. Kasur is famous for its very spicy fish, a sweet dish called Andrassay, and for its decorative embroidery. Shabana and her family have lived for 3 years in a two-room brick house that they own. Three of her daughters stay at home and do household work. Her youngest daughter goes to school. Shabana baji's husband drives an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle), a profession he has had for the last 2 years. Shabana baji prefers to do household work and take care of her family. She successfully repaid her first loan from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is applying for a loan of $525 to repair her husband's auto-rickshaw.

loans.use: To repair an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle)

loans.name: Thay

texts.en:
Mrs. Thay C. lives in Tumpoar Village in the Kampong Cham Province and is a pig breeder who raises ten pigs. Her husband, Mr. Yin Khan, is a healer in the local village. Mrs. Thay C. is 28-years-old and the mother of two children, one of whom is enrolled in school while the other, age four, is too young to work or study.

Since this business is going well, she has decided to ask for a loan to buy more piglets for breeding and she would use the rest of the money to buy pig food for them. Her husband is on the right of the photo.

loans.use: To buy more piglets for breeding and to buy pig food for the animals.

loans.name: Thay

texts.en:
Mrs. Thay T. is a farmer and pig breeder in Tumpoar Village in the Kampong Cham Province. Her husband, Mr. Eak Thuok, is a farmer and he also helps with his wife's business. Mrs. Thay T. is 34-years-old and the mother of three children who are all attending school.

She currently has only three pigs but they are very healthy. Since this business is going well, she wants to expand and is requesting a loan to buy more piglets for breeding and buy more pig food to feed them. Her husband is on the left in the photo.

loans.use: To buy more piglets for breeding and to buy more pig food to feed the pigs.

loans.name: Phoung

texts.en:
Mrs. Phoung S. was born in 1969 and lives in Tumpoar Village in the Kampong Cham Province. Her husband, Mr. Tuy Chen, is a construction worker who can earn three dollars per day which is too small of an income to meet the needs of the family. The couple has two children who are both enrolled in school.

She is a farmer who currently faces a small problem because her field has infertile soil which affects the harvest of her crop. She is requesting a loan to buy more fertilizer to improve her soil and would use the balance of the loan to buy chicken feed. Her husband is shown on the left of the photo.

loans.use: To buy more fertilizer to improve the soil for farming and to buy chicken feed.

loans.name: Sek

texts.en:
Sek Y., age 33, works raising pigs from her home and makes $2 a day. Her husband, Yun Ka, age 37, runs a business selling fish at an open air market and earns approximately $5 a day. This couple has four children and all of them are students. Mrs. Sek would like a loan from Kiva via Credit of $800 to increase the number of fish she sells. This is good for his business since there are many customers. Cambodian people prefer fresh water fish rather than salt water fish. (Yun Ka is pictured because his wife was not available)

CREDIT MFI is an independent Cambodian faith-based organization. It aims to empower the economically active poor and small entrepreneurs by providing inclusive financial services.

loans.use: To increase the number of fish sold

loans.name: Nov

texts.en:
Mrs. Nov N., 59, lives in Ta Koch Village in the Kampong Cham Province. She owns a small grocery store in the local market. Her husband, Mr. Min Chhom, is a farmer who cultivates twice a year. The couple has four children, two of whom are construction workers while another is a grocer. The youngest one is enrolled in the local school.

On his rice plantation, Mr. Min Chhom faces a small problem because he does not have enough money to hire a laborer to cultivate rice. Mrs. Nov N. decided to ask for a loan for this purpose and she would use the rest of the loan to buy fertilizers to support the field. Her husband is shown on the right of the photo.

loans.use: To hire a laborer to help cultivate rice and to buy fertilizers to support the field.

loans.name: Maria Dolores

texts.es:
María Dolores V. D. Laínez vive en el municipio D. Lourdes en el departamento D. La Libertad.  Como madre D. dos hijos, que cursan sus respectivos estudios académicos, María se ve constantemente en la necesidad D. mantener un equilibrio entre sus responsabilidades económicas, y las responsabilidades D. crianza, para con sus hijos.
DesD. hace ya dos años, María Laínez, abrió un pequeño negocio D. Bazar D. ropa. Lastimosamente, su negocio no alcanzó la demanda necesaria, lo que derivó en perdida. María, mediante fe y perseverancia, reconstruyó su negocio, ampliando sus ventas y ofreciendo nuevos productos, como papelería, útiles y ropa interior. María solicita un préstamo para surtir D. productos su nuevo negocio, y comprar nueva mercadería, que le permita darle nueva vida a su microempresa y mejorar la calidad D. su vida familiar.
texts.en:
María Dolores V. D. Laínez lives in the municipality of Lourdes in the department of La Libertad. As a mother of two children who are students, María constantly sees the need to maintain a balance between her economic responsibilities and those of raising her children.

It’s already been two years since María Laínez opened a small clothing shop. Sadly, her shop did not have the needed demand which resulted in loss. María, through faith and perseverance, rebuilt her business, increasing her sales and offering new products, like stationery, tools, and underwear. María requests a loan to stock products in her new business and to buy new merchandise that will allow her to give a new life to her enterprise and to improve the quality of her family’s life.

Translated from Spanish by Joanna Silverman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of merchandise and products for the store

location.town: Lourdes Colón, departamento de La Libertad

loans.name: Lim

texts.en:
Mr. Lim V., 34, is a vegetable farmer in Serey Sokhom Village in the Kampong Cham Province. His wife, Mrs. El Kimsun, helps him on the farm. The couple has two children, both are enrolled in the local school.

They own a half hectar which is a large piece of land for them to work by themselves. In order to cultivate the vegetables, Mr. Lim V. decided to ask for loan to hire a laborer to work with them in the field. His wife is on the right of the photo.

loans.use: To hire a laborer to help cultivate vegetables in the field.

loans.name: Bilquis

texts.en: Bilquis baji is a wife of M. and lives in Kasur, Pakistan. Kasur is famous for its sweetmeat and decorative embroidery. She has been living in this city for the last 20 years. She is the mother of six children: four daughters and two sons. Her daughters and her younger son are enrolled in a local school in her community. Bilquis baji's husband is a milk seller and has been in this profession for the last 20 years. Presently he has eight buffalos at his home and he gets milk from them by getting up at 4 AM. Bilquis baji helps her husband in getting milk from the buffalos. She successfully repaid her first loan from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is applying for a loan to buy another buffalo to expand her husband's milk business.

loans.use: To buy another buffalo to expand her milk business

loans.name: Youn

texts.en:
Mrs. Youn N., 47, lives in Serey Sokhom Village in the Kampong Cham Province. She is a vegetable farmer and owns a field that is three hectares. Her husband, Mr. Lay Sut, is raising five cows and also helps with his wife's business. The couple has one child who is employed in a garment factory.

Her field is covered with grass, thus she cannot grow vegetables. In order to solve this problem, Mrs.Youn N. has decided to ask for a loan to hire a laborer to chop the grasses so she may grow vegetables. Her husband is shown on the left of the photo.

loans.use: To hire a laborer to chop the all grasses in order to grow vegetables.

loans.name: Sakina

texts.en: Sakina baji T. D. is married with one daughter and lives in Kasur, Pakistan. Kasur city is famous for its spicy fish, a sweet dish called Andrassay, and for decorative embroidery. Sakina baji owns the two-room brick house where she and her family have lived for the last 10 years. Sakina baji's husband has been selling buffalo milk for 20 years. Sakina baji prefers to do house work and take care of her family at home. She is applying for a loan of $525 to buy another buffalo for her husband's dairy business.

loans.use: To buy another buffalo for her husband's dairy business

loans.name: Phorn

texts.en:
Mrs. Phorn L., 49, lives in Serey Sokhom Village in the Kampong Cham Province. She is the mother of six children, three of whom are employed in a garment factory and another child helps with the famiL. farm. The remaining two are attending school.

She and her husband, Mr. Korng Savann, own one field where they can grow potatoes. Their field is three hectares which is too large for them to cultivate potatoes without assistance. Mrs. Phorn L. decided to ask for a loan to hire laborers to work in the field. Her husband is on the left of the photo.

loans.use: To hire laborers to work in the field and cultivate potatoes.

loans.name: Hout

texts.en:
Hout H., 49, is a true entrepreneur and has a business selling groceries for her local people. On average, she makes US$3 of profit per day. Her husband, Hean Rith, 48, is a fisherman from the river. He always sells his catch to the market to earn approximately US$3 per day. This couple together has seven children; two of whom are students, three others are employed in different work. Mrs. Hout needs a loan from Kiva of US$800 to purchase a motorbike for transportation.

CREDIT MFI is an independent Cambodian faith-based organization. It aims to empower the economically active poor and small entrepreneurs by providing inclusive financial services.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for transportation.

loans.name: El

texts.en:
Mrs. El N., 22, is a farmer in Serey Sokhom Village in the Kampong Cham Province and is the mother two children who are both too young to work or to study in school. Her husband, Mr. Khem Ros, helps his wife's business.

She owns a one hectare field which is too large for the couple to cultivate vegetables by themselves. In order to solve this problem, Mrs. El N. decided to ask for a loan to hire laborers to work in the field. Her husband is on the left of the photo.

loans.use: To hire laborers to work in the field cultivating vegetables.

loans.name: Kalsoom

texts.en:
Kalsoom baji is married and lives in Kasur, Pakistan. Kasur city is famous for its spicy fish, a sweet dish called Andrassay, and decorative embroidery. She and her family have lived in this city for the last 6 years in a two-room brick house that they own. Kalsoom is the mother of three children: two sons and one daughter. Her elder son and her daughter are enrolled in a local school in her neighborhood. 
<paragraph>
Kalsoom baji's husband sells buffalo milk. He has been in this profession for the last 5 years and has one buffalo at his house. Kalsoom baji is a housewife and prefers to do household work and take care of the buffalo. She is applying for a loan to buy another buffalo for her husband's dairy business.

loans.use: To buy another buffalo for her milk business

loans.name: Yean

texts.en:
Mrs. Yean M. was born in1969 and now lives in Kokir Village in the Kampong Cham Province. She is a widow with four children, one is a construction worker and two children are employed in a garment factory. The youngest one attends school.

Mrs. Yean M. is a farmer who grows rice and vegetables. She owns one hectare of land which she uses for rice and she owns three hectares of land which she uses for vegetables. The vegetable field is too large for her to cultivate potatoes by herself, thus she decided to ask for a loan to hire laborers to work in the field. She hopes to improve her living conditions with this loan.

loans.use: To hire laborers to work in the vegetable field.

loans.name: Moa

texts.en: Mr. Moa S., 44, is married with five children and works as a construction foreman. He typically makes around $6 per day. His wife has started a business making and selling desserts for the people in her community. She makes around $5 of net income each day. The daily income she and her husband make is just enough to cover their family's expenses but is barely enough to have sufficient savings for emergency cases. In reality, each month this couple has to spend $96 on food, $10 on utility, $10 on their children's tuition and over $20 on gasoline spent by her husband as he uses his motor-bike to commute to work every day. In order to raise their daily income, this couple would like to ask for a loan from KIVA to buy their son a motor-bike to operate a motor-taxi business. This would greatly benefit their family's well-being.

loans.use: To buy her son a motor-bike to operate a motor-taxi business to generate additonal income for his family.

loans.name: Fakhira

texts.en:
Fakhira baji is the daughter of M. R. and lives in a city named Kasur, Pakistan. Kasur city is famous for its sweetmeats and decorative embroidery. Fakhira baji got a divorce after her one year of marriage. She has no children. She has been living with her family for the last 20 years.

After her divorce Fakhira baji didn't want to be a burden on her parents. Therefore, she gave her life a new turn and started a milk-selling business. She bought a buffalo and started getting milk from her. Now she has involved her brother in this business. She gets milk from the buffalo and he goes to sell the milk in milk shops. Now she and her brother are together in one business and they both decided to buy another buffalo.

loans.use: To buy another buffalo to expand her milk business

loans.name: Choem

texts.en:
Mr. Choem T. lives in Smaonh Village in the Kampong Cham province. He is a farmer who grows both rice and vegetables. His wife, Mrs. Choem Nhor, assists him in the field. They have three children who are all employed in different businesses.

Since these fields are too large for him to cultivate by himself, he has decided to ask for a loan to hire laborers to work in the field. With the balance of the loan, he would buy fertilizers to improve his soil.  His wife is on the left of the photo.

loans.use: To hire laborers to work in the field and to buy fertilizers to improve the soils.

loans.name: Sneg

texts.en:
Mrs. Sneg P., a farmer in Smaonh Village in Kampong Cham Province, cultivates both rice and vegetables. Since these fields are too large for her to work alone, she is requesting a loan to hire laborers and buy fertilizers for those fields. 

Sneg is 29 years old and the mother of four children, two of whom are attending school while the other two are of preschool age. Her husband, Mr. Yorn Chamrong, shown on the left in the photo, is a security guard.

loans.use: To hire laborers to work the field and buy fertilizers to support those fields.

loans.name: Qudrat

texts.en:
Qudrat U. is 24 and married; there are eight members in his family including his one-year-old, cute son. During the home war in Afghanistan, they lived in Pakistan for about 10 years as refugees, but now they have returned to their own district, Behsood, and are living in their village.

When Qudrat's family were living in Pakistan, he was a child and didn't work, but his father and older brother were working in a rented retail shop. There, life were going well, but when they returned home, they confronted some financial problems. Because they had to rebuild their destroyed home and buy some necessary equipment for their house with their own savings.

Qudrat's father was an active man and immediately started farming on their own lands. He grew rice and able to get US$ 1000 net profit from that. After a few months he bought a small retail shop for his son, and their problems were solving themselves day by day.

In the last 2 years, Qudrat's father has been faced with some serious illnesses and the doctors recommended him to rest.

Before his wedding, Qudrat U. was working with his brother in his shop, but when he got married, he decided to start an independent business. Definitely he had 150,000 Afghanis (US$ 3000) of his own capital, and he opened a retail shop in Jalalabad city and purchased some goods.

As Qudrat U. is as active as his father, he wants to expand his business more, and through it pave the way for his younger brothers to continue their studying, and have money to cure his sick father. For this purpose he doesn't have enough money, so he has requested from AFSG a 50,000 Afghani loan for 18 months. He wants to purchase rice, sugar, oil, and flour for his shop with this money, and increase his customer base.

Qudrat hopes that if he is able to achieve his goals, then he will change this business and will make a poultry farm. Because he thinks that those farms are more profitable than other businesses in this area. Finally he thanks honestly the lenders and their sincerity.

loans.use: To purchase rice, sugar, oil, and flour for his shop

loans.name: Ly

texts.en: Mrs. Ly S. is farmer in Smaonh village in Kampong Cham province. She owns one and half hectares for a rice field and four and half hectares for vegetables. Since these fields are too large for her to cultivate by herself, Mrs. Ly S. decided to ask for a loan to hire laborers to work in those fields and she would use the rest of the loan to buy fertilizer to support those fields. Her husband, Mr. Say Yon, is a healer in the local village. Mrs. Ly S. is 51 years old and the mother of two children who attend the local school. Her husband is on the left in the photo.

loans.use: To hire laborers and to buy fertilizer

loans.name: Khushal

texts.en:
This is Khushal K.. He is 21 and single. His parents and four brothers have been living in his village together for a long time. They have their own home in Behsood district. Khushal's father is about 60, and he can't do work, so he is resting at home.

When Khushal was about 7, he started tailoring with his father, and after 8 years he became a good tailor, and he is working as a tailor still now. Khushal and his brothers have a tailor shop in Behsood bazaar. They all provide the income for their family expenditures together.

But recently Khushal decided to make a cloth-selling shop besides his tailoring, because he thinks that this business will increase his income, and then he will expand his business more. But now he has 20,000 Afghanis of his own capital, and it's too little for this purpose, therefore he has requested a 50,000 Afghani loan for 18 months from AFSG. He wants to buy cloth with this money and with his own capital make some shelves in his shop.

Khushal hopes from the lenders that they will help him make his dreams come true and provide this opportunity for him. Also he thanks them in advance.

loans.use: To purchase cloth for his shop

loans.name: Nhorn

texts.en: Mrs. Nhorn S. H. is a villager in Smaonh village in Kampong Cham province. She is a vegetable farmer who grows potatoes in one hectare field. Since this field is too large for her to work with her husband, Mr. Yon Yong, she decided to ask for a loan to hire laborers to work in the field. Mrs. Nhorn S. H. is 20 years old and the mother of an eight-month-old child, who is too young to work or study. Her husband is shown on the left of the photo.

loans.use: To ask for a loan to hire laborers to work in the field to grow potatoes.

loans.name: Sayaad Rahim

texts.en:
Sayaad Rahim is 36 years old. He is married and the father of 3 children. He is a tailor. He has been involved in this business for more than 10 years. He has four workers in his shop. He was in Pakistan and he learned this business in Pakistan. Now he wants to grow this business better in Kabul to be a success and support his family well.

He wants to take out an individual loan of 42000 Afghanis with a term of 18 months to buy new machines for tailoring for his shop and enlarge his shop. He plans to sell to Afghani customers in the bazaar and become a good business dealer of Afghani clothes.

Sayaad Rahim is happy with this loan process in Afghanistan. He would like to thank both Kiva and AFSG in Afghanistan. He hopes that he can continue his partnership with Kiva and AFSG. He wants to send a special thank you to the lenders around the world.

loans.use: To buy new machines for tailoring

loans.name: Kong

texts.en: Mrs. Kong S. was born in 1974 and now lives in Smaonh village in Kampong Cham province. She is a farmer who cultivates both rice and vegetables. Her husband, Mr. Ly Sok Leang, is a breeder who is raising four cows, two buffaloes, and eight pigs. The pig breeding business is going well and his pigs are growing very fast, but he does not have enough money to buy pig food for them. So his wife, Mrs. Kong S., decided to ask for a loan to buy pig food for this purpose. Mrs. Kong S. has five children: three of whom attend school, while the remaining two are too young to work or enroll in school because they are three and five years old. Her husband is on the left of the photo.

loans.use: To ask for a loan to buy pig food.

loans.name: Ban

texts.en: Mr. Ban M. lives in Smaonh village in Kampong Cham province, where he is a farmer who cultivates both rice and vegetables. He owns a large field which he cannot cultivate with his wife. Thus, Mr. Ban M. decided to ask for a loan to hire laborers to work in the field. Mr. Ban M. is 42 years old and the father of seven children, three of whom are employed in different jobs while the remaining four are attending school. His wife is on the left of the photo.

loans.use: To ask for a loan to hire laborers to work in the field to cultivate potatoes.

loans.name: Pheng

texts.en: Mrs. Pheng S. was born in 1967 and now lives in Khvet Village in Kampong Cham Province. She is a single, female farmer who has a small piece of land to cultivate rice. Mrs. Pheng S. now faces a small problem because she does not have enough money to buy rice seeds so she decided to ask for a loan for this purpose. She hopes to improve her living conditions with this loan.

loans.use: To ask for a loan to buy rice seeds to cultivate.

loans.name: Sean

texts.en: Mrs. Sean P. lives in Roliek Village in Kampong Cham Province, where she is a farmer who owns a small rice field. After she gathers the rice, she gets a very small revenue with which she cannot support her family well. In order to improve her living conditions, Mrs. Sean P. decided to ask for a loan to buy a piece of land to cultivate rice to expand her rice revenues. Her husband is a foreman whose income is too small to support his family. Mrs. Sean P. is 31 years old and the mother of two children who are too young to work or study because they are one and four years old. Her husband is on the left of the photo.

loans.use: To buy a piece of land to cultivate rice to expand her rice revenues.

loans.name: Koung

texts.en: Mrs. Koung A. was born in 1950 and now lives in Roliek Village in Kampong Cham Province. She and her husband, Mr. Ya Chuon, are farmers. They now face a small problem because they do not have oxen to plow the rice field to cultivate rice. In order to deal with this problem, Mrs. Koung A. decided to ask for a loA. to hire a laborer with oxen to plow the field and to buy fertilizers to support her rice field. Mrs. Koung A. has three children, two of whom are employed as garment factory workers; the remaining child is enrolled in the local school. Her husband is on the left of the picture.

loans.use: To hire a laborer with oxen to plow and to buy fertilizers to support her rice field.

loans.name: Leng

texts.en: Mr. Leng T. lives in Nikon Leu Village in Kampong Cham Province. He and his wife, Mrs. Yin Heng, are farmers who cultivate both rice and vegetables. They own a 0.7 hectare rice field and three hectares for vegetable farming. Since these fields are too large for them to cultivate alone, Mr. Leng T. decided to ask for a loan to hire laborers to work in those fields. He would use the rest of the loan to buy fertilizers and pesticides to make his crop more productive. Mr. Leng T. is 40 years old and the father of four children: one is a laborer; two attend school; and the youngest child is four months old. His wife and daughter are shown with Mr. Leng T..

loans.use: To hire laborers to work in the field and to buy fertilizers and pesticides.

loans.name: Den

texts.en: Mr. Den D. lives in Srah Pring Village in Kampong Cham Province. He is a fisherman who now faces a small problem because he does not have enough money to buy more fishing equipments so he decided to ask for a loan for this purpose. His wife, Mrs. Oun Lay, is a farmer and a cow breeder. Mr. Den D. is 51 years old and the father of seven children two of whom are employed in different businesses while the remaining five are attending school. His wife is shown on the right of the photo.

loans.use: To buy more fishing equipment

loans.name: Eung

texts.en:
Mrs. Eung O., 44, is housewife staying home to care for her children and cook food for the family. Her husband, 39, is taxi driver, earning approximately US$ 6 per day. Eung has six children, all of whom are living in the family's home in Ratanak Commune, Battambang Province.

The family is helped by the eldest son who works as a construction worker to support the family. Now Eung O. faces obstacles with her husband's car breaking down. Hence, she would like to request a loan of US$ 700 to repair her husband's car which he drives as a taxi.

loans.use: To repair her husband's car which he drives as a taxi

loans.name: Both

texts.en:
This is the second time Mrs. Both P. has asked for a loan in order to improve her business activity. She lives in Ponlai Village in Kampong Chhnang Province. 

She is a tailor who processes cloth into dresses. Since this business is going well, she decided to ask for a loan to buy more fabric to meet the needs of her customers. 

Her husband, Mr. Vann Sarann, is a high school teacher who can make $50 per month. 

Mrs. Both P. is 29 years old and the mother of three children, one of whom is enrolled in the local school while the others are too young to work or study. Previously, Mrs. Both P. obtained a loan to buy piglets for breeding and she has fully paid it back.

loans.use: To buy more fabric to meet the needs of her customers.

loans.name: Erkinjon

texts.en: I. Erkinjon is 33 years old. He is married and he has three children. Erkinjon is providing taxi services with his vehicle. He has been in this business since 2004. He has many years' experience driving a taxi, which he does for a living five days a week. At the same time, Erkinjon is raising small cattle. Erkinjon buys calves on the market at a low price, feeds them and then resells on the same market at a more profitable price. His wife helps him to feed and look after the calves. Erkinjon is trying to make his business stable. These businesses generate the main income which allows Erkinjon to support his family. Because Erkinjon wants to provide high-quality taxi services, he is going to fix his car. In order to do this, he needs to purchase parts so he is requesting $450 for the term of 5 months. You can help him ensure the well-being of his family. He needs your help and he thanks you sincerely.

loans.use: To purchase spare parts for repairing taxi

loans.name: Twezimbe Women's Group

texts.en: N. Florence is the leader and chairperson of the Twezimbe women's group in Lugazi, Lweru village. She is a married woman who has eight of her own children as well as two orphans that she takes care of. In addition to farming, she raises cattle, poultry, and goats just to earn a living. She is so happy with these activities because each one helps her and her family in one way or another. She is asking for a loan that she hopes will help her pay the school fees for her six school-going children. She is planning to repay her loan by selling milk from her two cows as well as by selling produce like matooke, cassava, and sweet potatoes from her farm. She also says that the loan helps to pay the laborers that she employs on her farm under the direct supervision of both herself and her husband. She and her husband have become a successful team who plan together what to do next. So far they have acquired different plots of land and more animals. She is so grateful for her loans from Pearl Microfinance because what her family has now would not have been possible without them. And now she plans to buy hard corn that she can fry at home and sell to schools, shops and supermarkets for additional income.

loans.use: To buy hard corn

loans.name: Heung

texts.en:
Heung R., 23, is married and lives in Siem Reap, Cambodia. Since 2000, she has had a business selling fish in the market to earn a living and is able to make US$3 in profit each day. 

Her husband, Vann Nhun is 44 years old and has a business catching fish from the river for his wife to sell. Fishing is not stable income because he does not have enough fishing tools and there are many fishermen, too. Heung is asking for a loan from Kiva of US$500 to purchase more fish to sell in the market.

CREDIT MFI is an independent Cambodian faith-based organization. It aims to empower the economically active poor and small entrepreneurs by providing inclusive financial services.

loans.use: To purchase more fish to sell in the market.

loans.name: Kanoat

texts.en: K. Kanoat is a happy mother of three children. For two years, she has been selling foodstuffs like sweets, macaroni, preserved food, juices, soft drinks, tea, coffee and many others from her grocery store which she built near her house. Kanoat’s wish is to increase her business, offering a various types of foodstuffs to her customers who pass through those streets. She works with one aim in mind, to provide the best possible example and way of life for her beloved child, who is only 5 years old, who is the apple of her eye and the reason for her daily efforts. With this opportunity and with the immense love she feels as a mother and her desire to succeed, she is appealing to your generosity and is requesting a loan of $450 in order to increase her range of goods. She promises to repay the loan within 5 months. You can be an important link in the growth of this business by supporting her.

loans.use: To increase inventory

loans.name: Shamsiya

texts.en: K. Shamsiya is 45 years old. Since separating from her husband, she has raised her children alone. To provide for the family, and especially the children's education, she took to drying and remaking apricots. Thanks to Shamsiya's hard work, one of her children is now pursuing his studies elsewhere in the country. The high quality of her products has earned her a solid reputation among her customers and the demand for her goods has grown day by day. Today Shamsiya requests $1000 for the term of 12 months. She is going to use the loan for purchasing dried apricots with the purpose of processing and reselling. The only dream of Shamsiya is to grow her business so that she can keep educating her children. Shamsiya expresses her gratitude for everyone supporting her. Today you have the opportunity to help her make this dream a reality.

loans.use: Purchasing dried apricots

loans.name: Namiiro, Twezimbe Group

texts.en:
N. Aisha is the treasurer of Twezimbe Women's Group in Lugazi, Lweru village. She sells used clothes as her main business, without the benefit of a fixed location, but by walking around busy markets and taxi parks. She buys the clothing in bags or bales from Kampala, which usually include children's and ladies' clothing. This is not an easy job and most, like Aisha, would like to be able to afford to rent a storefront. She says that if she opens a shop in the future, she would want to keep up her current trade and, due to old age, maybe hire someone to do the moving around for her since it is also a profitable business.

Aisha has been in the business for a very long time. In fact it was her first business although she has added others, like farming on a small scale for both sale and home consumption, as well as owning two cows and poultry. She is married and has ten children and she cares for three orphans. She is paying school fees for 5 children. With her portion of the group loan, she plans to buy more used clothing to sell to her customers in the various markets.

loans.use: Namiiro Aisha plans to buy more used clothing to sell to her customers in the various markets.

loans.name: Thavy's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Thavy M., 35, is the leader of a small group and she works for the Catholic Temple in Ratanak Commune, Battambang Province, Cambodia. She has been working since 2000 and earns approximately US $3.20 per day. Her husband is a provincial policeman and earns around US $1.20 per day. They have one young child. To increase her family's income, Thavy runs a business selling rice. She is requesting a loan to purchase rice to resell.

The picture shows Thavy and her group members: Mrs. Sarorn R., who is requesting a loan to purchase the materials to make cakes to sell, Mrs. Khorn C., who is requesting a loan to use as capital for her fish-selling business, and Mr. Chamroen N., who is requesting a loan to use for his business selling soft drinks.

loans.use: To purchase rice to resell

loans.name: Abdumajid

texts.en: R. Abdumajid is 54 years old. He is married and he has three children. The two eldest are sons and the youngest is a daughter. His eldest son is married and has his own family. Abdumajid is an economist. With the purpose of improving his living conditions, he decided to start his own business. He learned two years ago about processing the apricot’s clingstone and runs his own business at home with the help of his friendly family. The business is very successfull and now Abdumajid needs a loan in order to meet customer demand. He is requesting a loan of $300 for the term of 9 months for purchasing more apricots. Abdumajid and his family sincerely thank you for your support.

loans.use: Purchasing apricots

loans.name: Vann

texts.en:
Vann H., aged 37, is married and lives with two of her children in Siem Reap, Cambodia. She makes around US$3 a day from selling fish. Her husband has a business catching fish from the river for his wife to sell. Their two their children are both students. Vann is asking a loan from Kiva of US$1,000 to help increase the number of fish she sells at the market.

(CREDIT MFI is an independent Cambodian faith-based organization. It aims to empower the economically active poor as well as small entrepreneurs by providing inclusive financial services.)

loans.use: To help increase the number of fish she sells at the market.

loans.name: Odilboy

texts.en: R. Odilboy is 22 years old. He lives in Isfara with his parents. Despite his young age, Odilboy has already become the main bread-winner in his family. Odilboy is a dynamic and ambitious young man who is very professional and focused on his business. He has a business selling cement at the building materials market. He has been in this business for 5 years and has gained a rich variety of experiences. He has a special warehouse where he safely keeps his goods. He knows how to save cement so that it doesn’t deteriorate. All this allows Odilboy to make his business quite successful and it brings in stable income for the family. With money from his business he is also able to pay for his university fees. Today, knowing that the price of the cement is low but will increase soon, he wants to purchase more goods. For this reason, he is asking a loan of $750 for the term of 6 months. He wants to use the money that he earns from his business to pay for his wedding. Odilboy expresses his gratitude to everyone for supporting him.

loans.use: Purchasing cement

loans.name: Umed

texts.en: U. Umed is 31 years old. He is married and he has 2 children. He has a successful business selling flour at the local market of Isfara town. Umed sells an assortment of good-quality flour. Because he buys the flour at wholesale, the price is cheaper than the price of his competitors. Thus, he has many customers who even purchase flour straight from his house. Today there is a great demand for his goods and that is why he wants to request a loan of $750 to add to his working capital and allow him to purchase more inventory. He promises to repay the loan within 6 months. He is ready to work even harder and make sacrifices to achieve his goal and become a successful entrepreneur. We believe his perseverance and clear vision will become key success factors in his small business.

loans.use: To buy flour for resale

loans.name: Birénam

texts.fr:
Madame K. Birénam est une revendeuse de charbon de bois très astucieuse. Née à Kara au TOGO en juin 1984, elle n’a pas fait de grandes études. Marié très tôt à un chauffeur de transport commun elle a aujourd’hui un enfant.
Profitant du véhicule de son mari, elle commande du charbon dans des villages et les revend à Lomé. Dans les villages où le charbon de bois est fabriqué et coûte moins cher qu’a Lomé. Elle a toujours bénéficié du crédit et rembourse bien.
Elle sollicite ce quatrième crédit pour acheter 10 sacs de charbon de bois et 10 fagots de bois de chauffe.
texts.en:
Ms. Birénam K. is a very astute retailer of charcoal. Born in June 1984 in Kara, TOGO, she did not have a lot of schooling. Married very young to a public transport driver, she now has a child. Making good use of her husband’s vehicle, she orders charcoal from villages and resells them in Lomé. Charcoal made in villages is less expensive than that in Lomé. She has always obtained loans and repays them without a problem. She is requesting this fourth loan to buy 10 sacks of charcoal and 10 bundles of firewood.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy firewood and charcoal

loans.name: Horng

texts.en:
Horng S. is 33 years old and works raising pigs on her plot of land near her house. She normally makes around US$3 per day. 

Her husband Tep Hang, 37, has a business making rice wine at his home to earn a living and is able to make US$5 a day. Rice wine is good and poor people like to drink it because it is cheap. 

To make more money, Horng is requesting a loan of US$1,000 to increase her livestock and purchase more feed for pigs. 

CREDIT MFI is an independent Cambodian faith-based organization. It aims to empower the economically active poor and small entrepreneurs by providing inclusive financial services.

loans.use: To increase her livestock and purchase more feed for pigs.

loans.name: Sidh

texts.en:
Sidh P., aged 37, is a true entrepreneur and has a business selling fish in the market. This earns her approximately US$5 a day. She told a Kiva loan officer that Cambodian people prefer to have freshwater fish rather than sea water fish. Her husband, Sor Navuth, aged 39, is a fortune-teller and makes US$3 a day to contribute towards supporting their family. The couple has four children, three of whom are students and one who is employed as a construction worker, building houses.

As the fish-selling business is bringing in more profit for the family, Sidh has decided to take out a loan of US$700 to increase the number of fish she sells, with the remainder of the loan to be used to renovate her house.

(CREDIT MFI is an independent Cambodian faith-based organization. It aims to empower the economically active poor as well as small entrepreneurs by providing inclusive financial services.)

loans.use: To increase the number of fish she sells and renovate her house.

loans.name: Tat

texts.en:
Mrs. Tat U., 40, is married with five children and works selling neat water for the people in her area. The majority of the people in the countryside lack neat water and are not yet covered by the state water provider. Mrs. Tat U. started her business in 2000 and typically makes about $2 income a day. Her husband works as a fisherman in TeleSap River which is a large lake rich in various kinds of fish. He has a boat with an engine and other fishing tools to help operate his business. Each day he makes around $5 income.

For many days, his boat engine has not been working properly and was frequently broken, being very old. Mrs. Tat U. and her husband are therefore requesting a loan from KIVA to purchase a new boat engine to replace her husband s old broken one and to buy more fishing nets.

loans.use: To purchase a new boat engine and fishing nets.

loans.name: Moussoulétou

texts.fr:
Madame M. Moussoulétou est née à Sokodé en 1968. Elle est mariée et est mère de trois enfants. Elle vit dans un quartier essentiellement commercial. Ainsi elle s’est lancée dans le commerce de divers articles en plastique, et certains produits de premières nécessités.
La concurrence étant rude elle a décidé d’aller vers les clients en faisant du porte à porte. Cette méthode lui a bien réussi ce qui fait qu’elle sollicite ce premier crédit pour ajouter à son stock d’autres produits. Ainsi avec ce crédit qu’elle sollicite, elle pourra acheter 25 glacières, 20 seaux en  plastique et un carton de savons.
texts.en:
Mrs.Moussoulétou M. was born in Sokodé in 1968. She is married and the mother of three children. She lives in a very commercial neighborhood. This is why she launched herself in the sale of various plastic goods, and some basic goods.

The competition was rough so she decided to go towards her clients by selling door to door. This method worked very well and she is requesting this first loan to add other products to her stock. With this loan she will be able to buy 25 ice chests, 20 plastic buckets and 1 box of soap.


Translated from French by Véronique Fourment, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of plastic goods, ice chests and soaps.

loans.name: Hamis Hussein's Jenga Grp Group

texts.en:
Hamis H., 32, is married with an 8-year-old daughter. He started a business eight years ago selling glass. His store is in an area known as Tabata. He works daily from 8:30 a.m. until 5 p.m. and earns a monthly profit of about $174.

Hamis has previously taken five loans from Tujijenge Tanzania. He used the loans to purchase land, build a house and increase the stock of his shop. With the loan he hopes to receive now, he plans to open a second glass shop in an area called Kariakoo, which is in the city center.

Hamis is the leader of Jenga group (meaning "build" in Swahili), which has 25 members. The members of the group hold each other accountable in paying back their loans. In the picture, Hamis is in the front row, second from the right in a blue shirt.

loans.use: To open a second glass shop in Kariakoo.

loans.name: Adidjatou

texts.fr:
Née à Sokodé en 1970, madame A. Adidjatou est mariée et mère d’une famille de quatre enfants. C’est une femme qui se bat pour aider son mari à subvenir aux besoins de safamille. Elle est commerçante comme son mari et elle vend des pagnes et des effets vestimentaires.
Elle est habituée à prendre du crédit et elle paye toujours bien. Grâce au crédit précédent son activité a évolué. Elle voudrait en prendre encore pour augmenter son stock de 56 pièces de pagnes.
texts.en:
Mrs Adidjatou Arolina was born in 1970, in Sokode. She is married and the mother of a family with four (4) children. This women fights hard to assist her husband in providing for the needs of the family. She is a business person, like her husband, and sells pagne (decorative cloth) as well as finished clothing.

She is experienced with making loans and has always repaid fully. Thanks to these previous loans her business has grown. She would like to make another loan to increase her stock with 56 pieces of pagne.

Translated from French by David Gibbons, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of 56 pieces of "pagne" (decorative cloth)

loans.name: Tatu Issa's Mbeya Group

texts.en:
Tatu I., age 25, is married with a one year old son. She owns a cosmetics shop, which she opened in 2007. She also has a beauty salon, which she opened earlier this year. She works daily from 8 am to 9 pm and is able to earn a monthly profit of $174 from the salon and $435 from her cosmetics shop.

This will be Tatu's first loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She is very excited for the opportunity! She intends to use the loan to increase the stock of her salon. Tatu is a subgroup leader of Mbeya Group. The members of the group hold each other accountable in paying back their loans. In the picture, Tatu is on the left in a red shirt.

loans.use: To increase stock of beauty salon.

loans.name: Aminétou

texts.fr:
Madame A. Aminétou est revendeuse de charbon dans un petit marché de Lomé. Née à Atakpamé en 1978, elle est aujourd’hui mariée et mère d’un enfant. Elle achète du charbon dans les villages environnants et le revend à Lomé.
Son réel problème étant le transport elle sollicite ce premier crédit pour acheter en grande quantité le charbon de bois pour un total de 15 sacs. Ainsi elle pourra réduire les voyages hebdomadaires d’approvisionnement afin de pouvoir économiser les frais de transport.
texts.en:
Mrs Aminetou A. is a retailer of charcoal in a small market place in Lomé. She was born in 1978 and today, is married and the mother of one child. She buys her charcoal in the neighboring villages and sells it in Lomé.

Her main problem has been with transportation and she is requesting her first loan to buy a large quantity (15 sacks) of wood charcoal. This way she would reduce the number of weekly purchasing trips and would save this cost of transport.

Translated from French by David Gibbons, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of 15 sacks of charcoal

loans.name: Mohamed Saidi's Nguvu Moja Group

texts.en:
Mohamed S., age 36, is divorced with three children ages 15, 8 and 3. He runs a business selling meat soup, which he started 4 years ago. He works from 6am until noon, but only sells soup every other day because he alternates with a friend. There would not be enough business if they both sold soup on the same days. He is able to earn about $4 per day which totals to about $60 per month. He also sells baskets in the market to supplement his income.

This will be Mohamed's sixth loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. He used the previous loans to buy a sofa set for his house and to purchase more utensils and pots to cook the soup. He paid back all the loans successfully. With the loan he hopes to receive now, he will increase his soup business.

Mohamed is a member of Nguvu Moja group (meaning "together we are one" in Swahili). The members of the group hold each other accountable in paying back their loans. In the picture, Mohamed is with his subgroup and is standing in the back row on the right. To his left is Juma Z. (salon owner). In front from left to right is Shani A. (clothing sales), Nasra S. (general store owner) and Halima A. (food vendor).

loans.use: To increase soup selling business.

loans.name: Pov

texts.en:
This is the second time Mrs. Pov S. has asked for a loan to improve her business activity. She now lives in Trapaing Chrai Village in Takeo Province, and she is a pig breeder. 

Since her business is going well, Mrs. Pov S. wants to expand it, so she decided to ask for a loan to buy eight more piglets for breeding. She would use the rest of the loan to purchase pig food. 

Her husband, Mr. Nop Nhen, is a construction worker who does not make enough income to support his family. 

Mrs. Pov S. is 47 years old and the mother of two children, one is a laborer in a rubber field while the other is attending school. Her husband is on the right in the photo.

loans.use: To buy eight piglets for breeding and pig food.

loans.name: Sok

texts.en: Mrs. Sok R. is a villager in Chi Chrap Village in Takeo Province. She is a farmer who faces a problem because her rice field now is infertile soil; thus, she decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizers to support the rice to produce a better crop. Her husband, Mr. Yi Sam Art, helps her in the rice field. Mrs. Sok R. is 38 years old and the mother of two children one of whom is employed in a garment factoR. while the other is attending school. Her husband is on the right of the photo.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer

loans.name: Atsu

texts.fr:
Monsieur N. est né à Tchébébé en 1968. Il est secrétaire dactylographe en chômage. Etant marié et père de deux enfants et pour faire face aux nombreuses charges familiales, il s’est lancé dans la vente de pétrole et de potasse.
Depuis 2006 qu’il a commencé cette activité il a connu une évolution.
Il a reçu une commande de 300l de pétrole, ce qui le pousse à prendre ce crédit pour satisfaire sa clientèle.
texts.en:
Mr. N. was born in Tchébébé in 1968. He is an unemployed secretarial typist. Being married and the father of two children, and to address numerous family responsibilities, he started selling kerosene and potash. Since 2006, when he began this business, he has experienced improvements. He has received an order for 300 liters of kerosene, which drives him to take out this loan to satisfy his customers.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy kerosene

loans.name: Aziza Kambi's Nguvu Moja Group

texts.en:
Aziza K. is 58 years old and divorced. She has four children ages 33, 30, 25 and 16. She started a business a long time ago of buying and selling scrap metal. She collaborates with some people who go around and collect the scrap metal. Aziza then buys the scrap metal from them and resells it to a warehouse or manufacturer for a profit. Her hours vary, but her profit is about US$ 30 per week.

This will be Aziza's sixth loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She used the previous loans to buy land, build a house and expand her business. She paid back all the loans successfully. She now hopes to receive another loan to have more capital to purchase more scrap metal.

Aziza is a member of Nguvu Moja group (meaning "together we are one" in Swahili). The members of the group hold each other accountable in paying back their loans. In the picture, Aziza is with her subgroup. She is standing second from the left.

loans.use: To expand her scrap metal  business

loans.name: Tith

texts.en:
Mr. Tith P. was born in 1986, and he now lives in Roneam Tnort Village in Takeo Province. 

He is single, and he is a farmer and duck breeder. Since his second business is going well, he wants to buy more ducks to raise, so he decided to ask for a loan to buy more ducks for breeding. He hopes to improve his living conditions with this loan.

loans.use: To buy more ducks for breeding.

loans.name: Kin

texts.en: Mrs. Kin C. lives in in Thmei Village in Takeo Province. She is a farmer and her husband, Mr. Oun Yeng, is a silk weaver. His business now is going very well and he has a lot of customers but it is difficult to take his product to his customers. In order to solve this problem, Mrs. Kin C., is asking for a loan to buy a second-hand motorbike for this purpose. Her husband is on the left of the photo.

loans.use: To buy a second-hand motorbike

loans.name: Dinh Thi

texts.vi:
Chị T. một mình nuôi 3 con, chồng chị bỏ chị theo vợ khác khi con nhỏ của chị mới được 3 tuổi. Tiến là con lớn của chị T.. Tiến bị bịnh tim bẩm sinh và não khi còn nhỏ và hiện cháu không được bình thường, đi khám Bác sĩ chẩn đóan bệnh tim giai đọan nặng cần phải mổ, vì bị bệnh nên Tiến chỉ học tới lớp 2 rồi nghỉ học. Hai em của Tiến còn đang đi học.
    Gia đình là hộ nghèo của địa phương, chỉ có 5 sào đất rẩy nhưng không trồng được hoa màu gì vì đất qúa xấu, đất bị bỏ trống 2 năm liền và hiện nay đang trồng điều. Khi chưa tham gia chương trinh thì T. nhập chỉ có 104.000đ/ người/tháng. Kể từ 03/2005 chị T. được dự án giúp vốn buôn bán, có vốn chị mua hàng nhiều hơn. Hiện nay chị đã được giúp 5 vòng, Chị trả góp hằng tháng và chị buôn bán có lời nên T. nhập cũng được cải thiện 125.000đ/người/tháng, tăng 21.000đ so với ban đầu.  Tuy T. nhập có tăng nhưng kinh tế còn rất khó khăn vì chỉ có 1 mình, vừa nuôi 2 con ăn học và 1 con bệnh. Chi T. mong muốn TC tiếp tục giúp vốn cho chị với số  vốn 1.000.000đ để chị vừa có vốn buôn bán và vốn đầu tư phân T.ốc vào 5 sào đất điều để có thêm tiền lo cho con. chị mượn vốn lần 2 của kiva
texts.en:
Ms. T. is a single parent of three. Her husband left her for another woman when her youngest child was only three years old. Tiến is Ms. T.'s eldest. Tiến was born with a heart condition and small brain; he is abnormal. His heart condition required surgery. Tiến only attending school up to second grade because of his condition. His two younger siblings are still in school. She is part of the poor population in her area. She has five sections of land but cannot grow any kind of vegetation because the soil is bad. The land has been bare for two consecutive years and is still that way today. Before participating in the fund program, her income was 104,000 VND per person, per month. Since March 2005, Ms. T. received assistance for a retail business. She used profits to purchase more inventory. Currently, she has received five rounds of assistance. She repays the loans monthly and her retail business is successful therefore her income has improves to 125,000 VND per person, per month; up 21,000 VND from before. Although her income has increased, her financial situation is still difficult because only has herself, while raising two school-aged children and one ill child. Ms. T. hopes to continue to receive the support from the program with a loan of 1,000,000 VND so that she can both put capital towards her retail business and invest in fertilizer for the five sections of land - to be able to provide for her children. This is her second Kiva loan.

Translated from Vietnamese by Catherine Tran, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To invest further in retail business and purchase fertilizer for gardening.

loans.name: Anela

texts.en:
Anela Omerović is 24 years old and she lives in little town, Kalesija, near Tuzla. She is married and she has a four-year-old daughter. Her husband is employed and he earns 1400 KM monthly. Anela wants to create better living conditions for her family, so she has decided to take a loan with WWI.

This is her first loan in the amount of 600 KM. She wants to buy poultry for fattening and selling. Anela hopes that she will have success in her business and that she will be able to work and sell more.

loans.use: To buy poultry to raise

loans.name: Kin

texts.en:
This is the second time Mrs. Kin C. has asked for a loan to improve her business. She lives in Pai Village in Takeo Province. 

She is a silk weaver and her husband, Mr. Yem Soeurnm, is a chicken breeder. Since Mrs. Kin C.'s business is going well, she wants to expand her business, so she decided to ask for a loan to buy 20 more kilograms of silk for weaving. 

She hopes she can sell at a better price in order to support her family. Mrs. Kin C. is 36 years old and the mother of five children, one helps in her business while the others are attending school. Her husband and the youngest child are shown on the right of the picture.

loans.use: To buy 20 kilograms of silk for weaving.

loans.name: Suvada

texts.en: Suvada A. ić was born in 1963. She is from a village called Dubnica, near Kalesija. Suvada lives with her husband and 14-year-old son. Her husband has regular work, and he earns 1100 KM monthly, so they are able to pay their daily costs. But Suvada wants to earn more; she wants to have her own income. That is her reason for taking the loan in the amount of 1000 KM. She will buy chickens for fattening and reselling. Her wish is to make a small poultry farm. She hopes that she and her son will do it together in the future.

loans.use: To buy chickens

loans.name: Mom

texts.en:
Mr. Mom M. was born in 1952, and he now lives in Pun Phnom Village in Takeo Province.  

He is a pig butcher who kills pigs for profit. His wife, Mrs. Kaing Song, owns small restaurant where she sells Khmer noodles to the villagers and visitors. 

Even though Mr. Mom M. and his wife have separate businesses, they still live in poor conditions. To improve their standard of living, Mr. Mom M. decided to ask for a loan to buy a cow for breeding. 

Mr. Mom M. is 56 years old and the father of two children -- one is employed in a garment factory while the youngest one is attending the local school. His wife is on the left in the photo.

loans.use: To buy a cow for breeding.

loans.name: Louise

texts.fr: Née le 20 novembre 1982 à Cotonou, dame A. Louise est célibataire sans enfants. Elle vit avec ses parents et n'est plus à leur charge. Elle vend des habits, des layettes et des chaussures qu'elle achete au Nigeria et au Togo. Pour augmenter son stock et pour repondre  à la demande sans cesse croissante de ses clients à la veille des fêtes de fin d'année, elle a sollicité ce prêt qui l'aidera à dynamiser son activité.
texts.en:
Born on November 20, 1982 in Cotonou, Ms. Louise A. is single and without children. She lives with her parents and is no longer in their care. She sells clothing, baby clothes, and shoes that she buys in Nigeria and in Togo. To increase her stock and to respond to the ever-growing demand of her customers on the eve of the year-end holidays, she has requested this loan, which will help her to pep up her business.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy 100 outfits for chldren and 50 shoes

loans.name: Hem

texts.en: Mrs. Hem S. lives in Pour Dos Village in Takeo Province. She is a farmer who cultivates her fields twice a year. She is a 58-year-old widow with a child who is a motorbike taxi driver. In this business, her child faces a small problem because the motorbike is too old and her child must spend a lot of money on petroleum. Thus, Mrs. Hem S. decided to ask for a loan to buy a new motorbike to replace the old one. Mrs. Hem S. hopes to increase her income and improve her living conditions with this loan.

loans.use: To buy a new motorbike taxi.

loans.name: Van

texts.en: Mrs. Van O. was born in 1973, and she is a villager in Prey Chheu Teal Village in Takeo Province. She is a farmer and her husband, Mr. Taing Sophat, is a construction worker who can earn $2.50 per day, which it is very little income to support his family. Although Mrs. Van O. and her husband both have businesses, they still cannot support their family. In order to improve their living conditions, Mrs. Van O. decided to ask for a loan to buy a cow for breeding. Mrs. Van O. is 35 years old and the mother of five children – one of whom is a construction worker, while another three are attending school. The youngest one is three years old and too young to work or study. Mrs. Van O.’s husband is on the right in the picture.

loans.use: To buy a cow for breeding

loans.name: Nut

texts.en: Mrs. Nut Y. lives in Prey Chheu Teal Village in Takeo Province. She is a basket maker. Since her business is going well, she wants to expand it so she decided to ask for a loan to buy more bamboo to make baskets in order to respond to customer demanded. Her husband, Mr. Chea Sophal, is a farmer and he also helps his wife when he has free time. Mrs. Nut Y. is 45 years old and the mother of four children who are all attending school.

loans.use: to buy more bamboo to make baskets

loans.name: Nguyen Thi Mai

texts.vi: Kinh tế còn khó khăn, không có đất rẩy chỉ có 2 sào ruộng làm đủ ăn khỏi mua gạo. Nghề chính của gia đình là chồng làm thuê quanh năm, mấy tháng nắng còn có công việc làm nhưng mùa mưa thì không có việc làm, còn vợ thì bán rau ngoài chợ mỗi ngày lời được 10.000đ nên thu nhập còn thấp đủ chi phí trong gia đình. Cuộc sống còn vất vả, con cho nghĩ học để phụ việc gia đình chỉ còn 1 con nhỏ đi học. chị vay vốn lại lần 2 cua kavi
texts.en:
Financial situations are hard. They have no garden or yard, only two sào (a Vietnamese measurement equaling to 360 square meters) of rice paddies which produces only enough so that she doesn't have to buy rice grains to eat. The family's main source of income is from her husband working as a year-round hired hand. During the sunny months he has job assignments, but not during the rainy months. Whereas, the wife sells produce at the market everyday for a profit of 10,000 VND. Their low income is only enough to cover their living costs. Life is still hard. Their children stay home (do not attend school) to help with family affairs; only the youngest is still attending school. This is their second loan through Kiva.

Translated from Vietnamese by Catherine Tran, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy bananas to sell at market.

loans.name: Therese Abeyonhou

texts.fr: Dama H. Therese Abeyonhou est née le 1er Septembre 1960 à AKPRO-MISSERETE dans le département de l'OUEME au sud du BENIN. Veuve ayant à sa charge quatre enfants tous scolarisés, elle se fait aider par une domestique nommée Suzanne pour la vente de tomates fraîches et du piment. Sa domestique est ambulante et vent dans les quartiers environnants tandis qu'elle même vend dans le marché de quartier DEGAKON. Elle s'approvisionne au marché HOUEGBO dans le département de l'Atlantique à 70 kilomètres de Cotonou. La tomate et le piment lui reviennent moins chers dans ce marché. Elle sollicite ce prêt pour renforcer son fonds de roulement.
texts.en:
Therese Abeyonhou H. was born on September 1, 1960 in Akpro-Misserete in the Oueme province of southern Benin. A widow with four school-aged children, she and her domestic employee Suzanne work together selling fresh tomatoes and peppers. Suzanne handles itinerant sales in nearby districts, while Therese has set up shop in the Degakon district market. She procures her stock from Houegbo in Atlantique province, 70 kilometers from Cotonou, as tomatoes and peppers are less expensive at that market. She is requesting this loan to increase her working capital.

Translated from French by Joyce K., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of 10 baskets each of fresh tomatoes and peppers

loans.name: Kong

texts.en:
Mrs. Kong S. is a villager in Kraing Bonteay Village in Takeo Province. She is a farmer who cultivates twice a year. Now, it is the rainy season and she needs to cultivate rice; unfortunately, she cannot do this plantation because she does not have enough animals to plow.

Thus, she has decided to ask for a loan to buy one more cow to add to the one she already has in order to plow the field. Her husband, Mr. Pon Paol, is a blacksmith who can make US$ 5 per day to support his family. Mrs. Kong S. is 36 years old and the mother of four children who are all enrolled in the local school. Her husband is on the right of the photo.

loans.use: to buy one more cow  in order to plow the field

loans.name: Kheng

texts.en:
Mr. Kheng S. was born in 1974 and he now lives in Kraing Raong Village in Takeo Province. He is an ice-cream seller who can make only a meager income to support his family. His wife, Mrs. Net Savy, is a farmer who now faces an obstacle in planting her fields because she does not have enough animals to plow the rice field.

In order to solve this problem, Mr. Kheng S. decided to ask for a loan to buy one more ox to add to the one he already has in order to plow the rice field. Mr. Kheng S. is 34 years old and the father of two children, one of whom is attending school while the other is too young to work or study because that child is only four years old. Mr. Kheng S.'s wife is on the left in the photo.

loans.use: to buy more one more ox in order to plow the rice field

loans.name: Blandine

texts.fr: Dama D. Blandine est née le 11 Juin 1968 à Cotonou dans le département du Littoral au sud du BENIN. Mariée à monsieur AKPLOGAN Emmanuel, elle est mère de cinq (05) enfants: Bertrand, Jeanne, Claudine, Pierrette et Charles. Seuls Pierrette et Charles sont encore à sa charge. Elle vend du pétrole et a déjà bénéficié de deux prêts à ALIDé. Pour s'approvisionner afin de combler l'attente de ses clients qui sont dans leur majorité des détaillants, elle sollicite le renouvellement de crédit pour l'obtention de son troisième prêt.
texts.en:
Ms. Blandine D. was born on June 11, 1968 in Cotonou, in the county of Littoral, in the south of BENIN. Married to Mr. Emmanuel AKPLOGAN, she is the mother of five children: Bertrand, Jeanne, Claudine, Pierrette, and Charles. Only Pierrette and Charles are still in her care. She sells kerosene and has already benefited from two loans with Alidé. To get her supplies in order to fulfill the expectations of her customers, who are mostly retailers, she is requesting this loan renewal as her third loan.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy 10 drums of kerosene

loans.name: Seangdy

texts.en:
Mrs. Seangdy C. and her husband, Mr. Phun Phoung, live in a small village along National Road Two about twenty kilometers south of Phnom Penh.  They were married in 1982 and have seven children: four sons and three daughters. Two of their children are employed full-time, and four children study at the local school. One child assists Seangdy in her business. 

Mrs. Seangdy has been selling porridge and fried noodles for four years. She cooks the food and sells it in front of her home early in the morning. He husband has health problems and stays at home. The main income in the family is from Seangdy and two of her children. Seangdy is requesting a loan of US$300 to dig a well for her family.

loans.use: To dig a well for the family.

loans.name: Celestine Dossi

texts.fr: Mariée à monsieur ZOCLANCLOUNON Bertin commerçant à Cotonou, dame F. Celestine Dossi est née le 11 Février 1962 à Adjohoun dans le département de l'OUEME au BENIN. Vivant avec son mari à PK10 dans la commune de SEME-PODJI, elle vend du ciment qu'elle achète à la SOCIETE DES CIMENTS DU BENIN SCB). Compte tenu de la cherté actuelle du ciment, de la rareté de ce produit et de l'écoulement rapide de sa marchandise, Dame F. Celestine Dossi  aimerait avoir un soutien financier pour l'approvisionnement. Elle a fait recours à ALIDé à travers un prêt pour atteindre son objectif.
texts.en:
Married to Mr. Bertin ZOCLANCLOUNON, a merchant in Cotonou, Ms. Celestine Dossi F. was born on February 11, 1962 in Adjohoun, in the county of OUEME in BENIN. Living with her husband in PK10 in the SEME-PODJI community, she sells cement that she buys at the SOCIETE DES CIMENTS DU BENIN SCB. Due to the current high cost of cement, its rarity, and the rapid turnover of her merchandise, Ms. Celestine Dossi F. would like to have financial support for her inventory. She has turned to Alidé for a loan to achieve her goal.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy six metric tons of cement

loans.name: Justine

texts.fr:
Née le 31 décembre 1965  à Lomé, elle est revendeuse des produits de premières nécessités à Lomé. Elle est mariée et mère de quatre (4) enfants qui vont à l’école. Elle est une femme dynamique qui a commencé cette activité depuis l’année 2000 dans son quartier.
Elle n’a jamais bénéficié du crédit auprès de WAGES et sollicite ce premier pour refaire son stock. Ce crédit lui permettra d’acheter 05 bidons d’huile végétale, 06 sacs de riz, 04 sacs de sucre en poudre et 06 cartons de savons. Ainsi avec le revenu de son activité, elle pourra aider son mari dans les dépenses de la famille.
texts.en:
Born on December 31, 1965 in Lomé, she is a re-seller of basic goods in Lomé. She is married and the mother of four (4) children, all attending school. She is an energetic woman who started this activity in her neighborhood in the year 2000.

She has never benefited from a credit from WAGES and is requesting this first one to replenish her stock. This loan will enable her to buy 5 cans of vegetable oil, 6 bags of rice, 4 bags of sugar, and 6 boxes of soap. With the income from her activity, she will be able to help her husband with household expenses.


Translated from French by Véronique Fourment, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of basic goods

loans.name: Chan

texts.en:
Mr. Chan C. and his wife, Mrs. Sochiet Long, live in a small village along National Road Two about twenty kilometers south of Phnom Penh.  They were married in 2003 and have one son and one daughter. 

Mr. Chan has been a construction worker for five years, while his wife stays at home to take care of their small children. She was a garment factory worker for many years. Chan lacks the money to build part of his house. Therefore, he is requesting a loan of US $200 to build a staircase for his house.

loans.use: To build a staircase for his house.

loans.name: Suy

texts.en:
Mrs. Suy N., 59 is a widow with seven children: three sons and four daughters. Two of her children are married and live away from home. One son is a driver and another is a monk. Three of her daughters are silk weavers.

Mrs. Suy has been selling silk products for ten years. She buys finished products from weavers in the village and then takes them to sell in Posat Province. Suy has four looms in her family for her daughters to weave silk at home.

Suy is requesting a loan of 1,000 to purchase silk materials for her daughters to continue their weaving business.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials for her daughters to weave.

loans.name: Sat

texts.en:
Mrs. Sat B. (in the middle with her daughters and grandchild), 56, is a widow with four daughters. Her oldest daughter is a fruit seller. She is married but still lives with Mrs Sat in their family home. Mrs Sat's three other daughters are garment factory workers. The family lives along the Tonle Basac River, a tributary of the nearby Mekong, about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Mrs. Sat has been selling clothes for twenty years. She buys secondhand clothes from the market in Phnom Penh for resale in her village and nearby villages. Currently, her eldest daughter (shown in the picture on the left) sells fruit in Phnom Penh and she needs a motor trailer to help carry her goods.

Thus, Sat is requesting a $600 loan to purchase a motor trailer for her daughter to carry fruit to sell at the market in Phnom Penh.

loans.use: To purchase a motor trailer for her daughter selling fruits.

loans.name: Virginie

texts.fr: Âgée de 41 ans, dame E. Virginie est mariée et vit avec son époux Jacob EBOUE, maître couturier. Elle vend du maïs, des biscuits et des bonbons qu'elle achète au marché Dantokpa. Pour couvrir la demande de ses clientes en maïs et s'approvisionner en biscuits, elle a fait recours à ALIDé en vue de l'obtention d'un prêt.
texts.en:
41-year-old Virginie E. is married and lives with her husband Jacob Eboue, a master dressmaker. She sells corn, cookies and candy, which she buys from the market in Dantokpa. To meet her clientele’s need for corn, and to increase her inventory of cookies, she has turned to Alidé for a loan.

Translated from French by Joyce K., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of 5 sacks of corn, 10 sacks of cassava flour, candy and cookies

loans.name: Bertchissou

texts.fr: D. Bertchissou est une femme née en 1952 à Sokodé, ville située au centre du Togo. Elle est mariée et mère de 2 enfants. Depuis 1990, elle a commencé la vente de pagnes et de draps dans les quartiers de Lomé. Elle était une revendeuse ambulante et distribue les pagnes et les draps à crédit de quartier en quartier et récupère l’argent après une semaine. Après obtention du premier crédit, elle a loué un magasin dans lequel elle expose ses marchandises. Cette activité qu’elle mène lui permet de subvenir à ses besoins et à celui de sa famille. Ce second crédit qu’elle sollicite lui permettra d’acheter 30 pièces de pagne et 20 draps.
texts.en:
Bertchissou D. is a woman who was born in 1952 in Sokodé, a city located in the middle of Togo. She is married and the mother of two children. In 1990, she started selling “pagnes” (colorful West African cloth) and sheets in the districts of Lomé. She used to be a door-to-door retail seller. She now distributes pagnes and sheets on credit from district to district and collects the money after a week. After obtaining an initial loan, she rented a store in which she displayed her merchandise. This business that she manages enables her to provide for her needs and those of her family. This second loan that she is requesting will enable her to buy 30 lengths of pagnes and 20 sheets.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy pagnes, sheets, and jewels

loans.name: Geronime Medelidji

texts.fr: Dame T. Geronime Medelidji est née vers les années 1968 à KPOE dans l'arrondissement de Kpanroun au centre du BENIN. Elle a épousé monsieur YEBLE Valère et est mère de 5 enfants dont 3 sont scolarisés. Vendeuse de condiments depuis bientôt 5 ans, elle s'approvisionne à DANTOKPA. Elle sollicite ce crédit pour s'approvisionner en maïs, en haricot et en farine de manioc afin d'accroître son activité et de satisfaire ses clients qui ne cessent chaque jour d'en faire la demande.
texts.en:
Mrs. Geronime Medelidji T. was born around 1968 in Kpoe in the Kpanroun arrondissement in central Benin. She is married to Mr. Valère Yeble and has five children, three of whom are in school. She has sold various food products for the past five years and she gets her stock in Dantokpa. She is requesting this loan to purchase corn, beans, and cassava flour so she will be able to keep up with her daily customer demand.

Translated from French by Manuel Carreiro, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of three sacks of corn, three sacks of beans, and three 50-kg sacks of cassava flour

loans.name: Ahoéfa Sonia

texts.fr:
Née le 17 octobre 1983 à Lomé, Madame M. Ahoéfa Sonia est mariée et mère de deux (2) enfants. Elle a pour activité principale la vente des bijoux dans l’un des marchés locaux de la ville de Lomé. Elle a commencé cette activité depuis 2003 et a des clients fidèles.
Ce premier crédit qu’elle sollicite lui permettra d’aller faire des achats de 30 colliers et 50 paires de boucles d’oreilles.
texts.en:
Born on October 17, 1983 in Lomé, Mrs. Ahoéfa Sonia M. is married and the mother of two children. Her primary business activity is the sale of costume jewelry in one of the local markets of the city of Lomé. She began this business in 2003 and has a faithful clientele.

This first loan that she is requesting will allow her to purchase 30 necklaces and 50 pairs of earrings.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of costume jewelry for re-sale

loans.name: Paoline

texts.fr: Dame H. Paoline est née le 20 octobre 1980. Elle est mariée et mère d'un enfant âgé de 4 ans. Elle achète des mèches synthétiques au NIGERIA , qu'elle vient vendre dans son salon de coiffure à ses clientes afin de leur faciliter le déplacement et la rapidité dans son travail. Du fait de  l'approche des fêtes de fin d'année et compte tenu de la demande de ses clientes l'année précédente, elle s'est rapprochée de ALIDé afin de bénéficier d'un prêt pour faire face à aux demandes de sa clientèle.
texts.en:
Born on October 20, 1980, Paoline H. is married and the mother of a 4-year-old child. She buys synthetic hair extensions in Nigeria and brings them back to sell to clients in her hair salon. In order to avoid making the trip, permitting her to work faster, in anticipation of the approaching year-end holidays, she has approached Alidé for a loan based on last year's customer demand to meet the needs of her clientele.

Translated from French by Joyce K., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of two cases of synthetic hair extensions

loans.name: My Chepel Group

texts.fr:
Créée depuis plus de deux ans entre les femmes solidaires des quartiers d’Agoè, l’association MY CHEPEL a pour objectif l’entraide mutuelle. Les femmes de cette association sont mariées et ont tous des enfants à charge. Leurs activités commerciales varient d’un membre à un autre. Ces activités sont entre autre la vente du riz, du charbon de bois, des produits génériques, des chaussures, des pagnes et des céréales. Les revenus de leurs activités leur permettent de venir en aide à leur mari dans les dépenses de la famille. Elles ont toujours obtenu des crédits auprès de WAGES et remboursent toujours bien.
Ce quatrième crédit que cette association sollicite lui permettra de faire des achats de 8 cartons de produits génériques, 10 douzaines de chaussures, 7 sacs de riz et 2 sacs de maïs.
texts.en:
Over two years ago, among the solidarity women of the districts of Agoè, the association MY CHEPEL was created with the goal of mutual support.
