This leads to poor financial support hence poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. Where a client needs working capital SELFINA buys equipment from said client, extending a loan to her, then leasing back the same equipment Ð a process called a sale and leaseback arrangement

loans.use: To buy medications and bulk chicken feed

loans.name: Leat

texts.en: Leat C., 45, is a true entrepreneur and has a business selling fish at the market. She earns approximately US$4 each day. Her husband catches fish from the river for his wife to sell and he also plants many kinds of vegetables. Sometimes he only catchs a few fish so she needs to order more fish from other fisherman. This couple has five children and all of them are students. The weather conditions have been difficult in Cambodia this past year and inflation has also been out of control. These factors have played into a difficult economic year for many Cambodians, Leat C. included. Leat would like a loan of US$800 to buy more fish to sell in the market. Currently, she has many customers but sometime she does not have enough fish to sell.

loans.use: To buy fish to sell in the market.

loans.name: Rustam

texts.en: Rustam P. is 28 years old. He is married with two children. Rustam provides taxi services with his car. He has been in this business for the last ten years. Rustam has always tried to provide services of high quality -- but at the same time attractive prices -- for the customers. Rustam is doing his best to make his business stable and profitable, as he is the main bread-winner in his large family, which includes his parents. He is ready to work from the early morning until the late night in order to keep his customers and obtain new ones. Today, as the price of the petrol is rising day by day, he is planning to replace the fuel supply system to make it more economical than a standard gas system. For this reason, he requests $1,000 for the term of 12 months. He thanks everyone supporting him and promises to repay the loan in a timely manner. The well-being of this family is in your hands.

loans.use: To replace the car's fuel supply system

loans.name: Luth

texts.en:
Mrs. Luth L., 25, is married with two little children and has been working as a rice farmer since 2005, making about $2 each day.

Her husband is meanwhile self-employed as a construction foreman and typically earns about $5 each day. Mrs. Luth L. would like to request a loan from KIVA to purchase more fertilizers and farming tools to accelerate her work as well as to keep expanding her crops. (Her husband is pictured because Mrs. Luth L. was not available.)

loans.use: To purchase more fertilizer and farming tools

loans.name: Grace S.

texts.en:
Mambo from Mbeya, Tanzania! This is 30-year-old Grace N..  She is married and has three children aged 5, 9, and 12. In 2007, Grace established her hair salon business. She opens her business 7 days a week, 9-12 hours a day. Grace requires a loan to buy more salon equipment. She thanks you for your support.  

Hair, hair and more hair! This is the place where you can buy long hair, short hair, curly hair, straight hair, red hair, blue hair, and then have it attached to your head, woven, cut, or plaited, and made to look like your own.

loans.use: To buy more hair salon equipment.

loans.name: Sean

texts.en:
Sean C., 30, is married with two young children living at home in the Siem Reap province. She and her husband, Nin Phat, work together catching fish from the river and then selling their catch at the local market. They earn approximately four dollars each day.

Sean also owns another business selling food products from her home. Soft drinks, beer, cake and ice are a few of the products she sells to the people in her area. The two businesses are going smoothly but she still needs more income to improve her standard of living.

She has told a loan officer that she wants her children to take a higher class so they will be able to get better jobs in the future. To double the family's income, she is requesting a loan of US$500 to add to the number of fish they sell in the market. The balance of the loan will be used to purchase more fishing tools.

loans.use: To increase the number of fish to sell at the market and to purchase more fishing tools.

loans.name: Emmy H.

texts.en:
Mambo from Mbeya, Tanzania! This is 30-year-old Emmy M..  She is married and has one child, aged 6. In 2007, Emmy began poultry farming. She opens for business seven days a week, and works 9-12 hours a day. She is assisted by her husband. Emmy requires a loan in order to buy medicine and bulk feed for her chickens. She thanks you for your support.  

SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facility as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed not-creditworthy by financial institutions as they lack tangible collateral assets. This leads to poor financial support hence poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. Where a client needs working capital SELFINA buys equipment from said client, extending a loan to her, then leasing back the same equipment Ð a process called a sale and leaseback arrangement

loans.use: To buy chicken feed and medicine

loans.name: Bertha E.

texts.en:
Mambo from Mbeya, Tanzania! This is 36 year old Bertha M.. She is married with four children, aged between 10 and 18. In 2006, Bertha established a grocery business, which is open six days a week for sixteen hours a day. Bertha has already received and successfully repaid two loans from SELFINA. She now requires a loan to buy more beer and crates of soft drinks in bulk. She thanks you for your support.

SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facility as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed not-creditworthy by financial institutions as they lack tangible collateral assets. This leads to poor financial support hence poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. Where a client needs working capital SELFINA buys equipment from said client, extending a loan to her, then leasing back the same equipment, a process called a sale and leaseback arrangement.

loans.use: To buy more beer and crates of soft drinks in bulk.

loans.name: Pum

texts.en: Pum V., 46, is a widowed farmer who lives with four of her children. Living in Siem Reap province, she typically makes about US$4 each per day and two of her children make about US$2.50 each day as broom makers. Pum has requested a loan of US$250 to purchase fertilizers to put on her farm. Farming is a hard way to support the family, as the weather conditions are difficult and she uses a lot of energy, but earns little. In the future, she plans to set up a grocery store.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers.

loans.name: Terezia M.

texts.en:
Mambo from Mbeya, Tanzania! This is 35-year-old Terezia B..  She is married and has four children between the ages of 10 and 17. In 2003, Terezia established her crops business. Terezia has already received and successfully repaid two loans from SELFINA, and now requires a new loan in order to buy more crops in bulk. She thanks you for your support.  

SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facility as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed not-creditworthy by financial institutions as they lack tangible collateral assets. This leads to poor financial support hence poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. Where a client needs working capital SELFINA buys equipment from said client, extending a loan to her, then leasing back the same equipment Ð a process called a sale and leaseback arrangement

loans.use: To buy more crops in bulk

loans.name: Thị Thơm Lê Group

texts.vi:
Chị Lê Thị Thơm 37 tuổi mã số 09010005 làm thợ may, chị khéo tay nổi tiếng trong vùng. Của hàng của chị khá đong khách. Chị có chồng và 2 con đang học cấp I. Ngoài làm may chị còn trông lúa và nuôi khoảng gần 500 con gà đẻ trứng. Thu nhập hàng ngày gần 200.000đ. Chị cùng cả nhóm đã tham gia vay được 1 chu kỳ và hoàn trả vốn vay tốt. Chị làn này vay 4.704.000đ để mua cám gà và vải để làm may. Trong nhóm chị còn có 4 người khác nữa.

  • Chị H. Thị Nhung mã số 09010008 vay 4.256.000đ để mua giống và cám nuôi gà thịt
  • Chị H. Thị Tuyển mã số 09010009 nvay 4.256.000đ để mua cám và giống gà đẻ trứng
  • Lê Thị Hạnh 09010014 vay 3186.000 thời hạn là 12 tháng để mua cám và gà đẻ.
  • Vũ Thị Minh mã số 09010015 vay 3186.000 thời hạn là 12 tháng để mua cá giống và lợn
    • .
texts.en:
Mrs Lê Thị Thơm is 37 years old. She is a seamstress, well know for her skill. She has a good clientele. She is married and has 2 children who attend school. Beside sewing, she works in their rice field and keeps 500 egg laying chickens. Her income is around 200.000 VND a day. Her group has already paid back successfully their first group loan. This time she is requesting 4.704.000 VND to buy feed for her chickens and fabrics. Other members of her group are:
  • Mrṣ H. Thị Nhung, she needs 4.256.000 VND to buy feed and chickens
  • Mrs H. Thị Tuyển, she needs 4.256.000 VND to buy feed and chickens
  • Mrs Lê Thị Hạnh, she needs 3186.000 VND to buy feed and chickens.
  • Mrs Vũ Thị Minh, she needs 3186.000 VND to buy piglets and breeding fishes
    • .

    Translated from Vietnamese by Khang Ho-Si, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy fabrics and chicken feed

loans.name: Lydia J.

texts.en:
Mambo from Mbeya, Tanzania! This is 46-year-old Lydia M..  She is married and has four children between the ages of 11 and 26. In 1998, Lydia established her rice-selling business. Lydia has already received and successfully repaid four loans from SELFINA, and now requires a new loan in order to buy more inventory of rice. She thanks you for your support.  

SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facility as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed not-creditworthy by financial institutions as they lack tangible collateral assets. This leads to poor financial support hence poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. Where a client needs working capital SELFINA buys equipment from said client, extending a loan to her, then leasing back the same equipment Ð a process called a sale and leaseback arrangement

loans.use: To buy more inventory.

loans.name: Inick J.

texts.en:
Mambo from Mbeya, Tanzania! This is 23-year-old Inick M..  She is married and has a one-year-old child. In 2007, Inick established her crops business. Working 6 days a week, and 9-12 hours a day, she earns about US $260 every month from this business. She is assisted by her husband. Inick has already received and successfully repaid two loans from SELFINA, and she now requires a new loan in order to buy more maize. She thanks you for your support.

loans.name: Esther A.

texts.en:
Mambo from Mbeya, Tanzania! This is 45 year-old Esther M..  She is divorced and has three children, aged 19, 20, and 23. She has two additional dependents who live with her because they are orphans. Esther established her crops business in 2005. Working 7 days a week, and 16 hours a day, she earns about US $40 every month from this business. She is assisted by her sister. Esther has already received and successfully repaid three loans from SELFINA, and now requires a new loan in order to buy more crops in bulk. She thanks you for your support.  

SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facility as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women.

loans.name: Saada

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 24-year-old Saada S. from Mwanza. She is married with one child, aged seven. Saada has been running a maize business since 2006. Client's business is selling maize. She works at the business for twelve hours per day, six days per week and is assisted by three employees. Saada currently earns about 200usd from her business. She is requesting a loan of 350usd in order to buy more maize. In the future, she plans to increase the stock quantity. Saada thanks you for her support!

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of microleasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To buy more maize

loans.name: Maria A.

texts.en:
Mambo from Mbeya, Tanzania! This is 34-year-old Maria M..  She is widow and has four children, aged between 10 and 16. In 2002, Maria established her rice-selling business. Working 2 days a week, and 9-12 hours a day, she earns about US $40 every month from this business. Maria has already received and successfully repaid two loans from SELFINA, and now requires a new loan in order to buy additional inventory of rice. She thanks you for your support.  

SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facility as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women.

loans.name: Catherine J.

texts.en:
Mambo from Mbeya, Tanzania! This is 31 year old Catherine N.. She is married with three children, aged 2, 6, and 9. In 1998, Catherine established a "genge" business. She is assisted by her husband. Working seven days a week, and nine to twelve hours a day, she earns about $170 a month from this business. Catherine has already received and successfully repaid one loan from SELFINA. She now requires a loan to renovate the business. In the future, Catherine also plans to invest in other businesses. She thanks you for your support.

Genge is a Swahili word for a type of outside shop, or stall. A genge is usually a very basic structure made of wood, with a tin roof, that sells general items, such as onions, tomatoes, chilli, oil, rice, and dried fish. It is the kind of place local people usually send their children running to fetch something when they are in the middle of cooking the evening meal, and don't have time to go all the way to the market to buy the missing ingredient.

loans.use: To renovate her business.

loans.name: Mary Y.

texts.en:
Mambo from Mbeya, Tanzania! This is 40-year-old Mary A..  She is widow and has two children, aged 12 and 20. She also has two dependents who live with her because they are orphans.  In 2005, Mary established her hair salon business. Working 6 days a week, and 9-12 hours a day, she earns about US $40 every month from this business. Mary has already received and successfully repaid one loan from SELFINA, and now requires a new loan in order to buy more cosmetics and different styles of hair products. She thanks you for your support.  

Hair, hair and more hair! This is the place where you can buy long hair, short hair, curly hair, straight hair, red hair, blue hair, and then have it attached to your head, woven, cut, or plaited, and made to look like your own.

loans.use: To buy more cosmatics and different morehair styles.

loans.name: Saada

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 24-year-old Saada S. from Mwanza. She is married with one child, aged seven. Saada has been selling maize since 2006. She works at the business for 12 hours per day, 6 days per week, and is assisted by three employees. Saada currently earns about US$200 from her business. She is requesting a loan of US$350 in order to buy more maize. In the future, she plans to purchase larger  quantities of stock. Saada thanks you for her support!

loans.name: Noeun

texts.en: Mr. Koeun L., 36, a fisherman earning approximately US$2.00 per day, lives in Peam Ek Commune, Battambang Province. His wife, Mrs. Chem Cho, 33, is a housewife and stays home to care for the children and cook food for the family. Koeun has three young children; all of them are students and live in the family's home. With his growing business, he needs more fishing equipment. Hence, Koeun seeks a loan of US$200 to purchase nets. The loan will improve his business and increase the profit for his family.

loans.use: To purchase nets to catch fish

loans.name: Amina

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 32-year-old Amina M. from Mwanza. She is married with two children, ages 12 and 14 years. Amina has been running a beauty salon (called a "saloon") since 2003. She works at the business for 8  hours per day, 7 days per week, and she is assisted by one employee. Amina currently earns about US$170 from her business. She is requesting a loan of US$450 in order to purchase more equipment for her salon such as  a hair drier, weavings, and hair tonic. In the future, she plans to increase her equipment and have a better quality office. Amina thanks you for your support!

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of microleasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase beauty shop equipment

loans.name: Matrida

texts.en:
This is 42-year-old Matrida P. from Mwanza. She is widowed with three children between the ages of 18 and 22 years. Matrida has been raising cows and selling milk since 1995.  She works at the business for eight hours per day, seven days per week, and she is assisted by one employee. Matrida currently earns about US$250 from her business. She is requesting a loan of US$450 to buy more cows. Matrida thanks you for her support!

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro leasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To buy more cows

loans.name: Witness B.

texts.en:
Mambo from Mbeya, Tanzania! This is 44 year-old Witness S..  She is married, and has four children, aged between 23 and 15 years. In 2005, Witness established her "genge" business. Working six days a week, and 13-16 hours a day, she earns about US $40 every month from this business. She is assisted by her husband. Witness requires a loan in order to purchase more rice, sugar, salt, and cooking oil in bulk. In the future, Witness plans to estabilsh another business. She thanks you for your support.  


The Swahili word for this type of outside shop, or stall, is "genge." A genge is usually a very basic, wooden and tin-roofed structure where general items such as onions, tomatoes, chilli, oil, rice, and dried fish are sold. It is the kind of place to which local people usually send their children running to fetch something when they are in the middle of cooking the evening meal and don't have time to go all the way to the market to buy the missing ingredient.

loans.use: To purchase inventory in bulk.

loans.name: Hellena

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 38-year-old Hellena M. from Mwanza, who is married with five children between the ages of 11 and 21.  Hellena has been running a café business since 1997, selling food, tea, and coffee. Working at the business for ten hours per day, six days per week and assisted by three employees. she currently earns about $300 a month. 

Hellena is requesting a loan of $450 in order to buy rice, wheat flour, sugar, and cooking oil, and in the future plans to increase the quantity and range of her stock. She thanks you for your support!

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility.

loans.use: To buy rice, wheat flour, sugar, cooking oil, and maize flour

loans.name: Neema

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 43-year-old Neema Mhilane from Mwanza. Married with two children aged 18 and 25, Neema has been selling chickens since 2006.  Working at the business for nine hours a day, seven days per week, she currently earns about $200 a month. She is requesting a loan of $450 in order to buy more chickens, and in the future  plans to buy even more.  Neema thanks you for your support!

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility.

loans.use: To buy more chickens

loans.name: Khiev

texts.en:
Mrs. Khiev M. is a villager in Andoung Samreth Village in Takeo Province. She and her husband, Mr. Kheiv Sophorn, are farmers. Since their plantation field is far from irrigation, Mrs. Khiev M. has decided to ask for a loan for a pump to generate water to water her field. Additionally, she can hire it out to other villagers for an income.

Aside from this, her husband is a laborer who uses their two oxen to plow other villagers' fields for an income. Mrs. Khiev M. is 46 years old and the mother of a child who is attending the local school. Her husband is on the right in the photo.

loans.use: for a pump to generate water to water her field

loans.name: Toem

texts.en: Mrs. Toem N. lives in Trapaing Srang Village in Takeo Province. She is a farmer and grocer. With her plantation last year, she had an income of $525. Her husband, Mr. So Sopheon, is a fisherman who makes a very small income. Although Mrs. Toem N. and her husband have different businesses, they still cannot support their family well, so Mrs. Toem N. decided to ask for a loan to buy a secondhand motorbike for her husband so he can start a motorbike taxi in the local village. Mrs. Toem N. is 28 years old and the mother of two children:  one is enrolled in the local school and the other is too young for school. Her husband is on the left in the photo.

loans.use: To buy a secondhand motorbike.

loans.name: Tran Thi

texts.en: Mrs. Tran Thi K. is 40 years old. She joined TYM Fund in 2004. During 4 years, she invested most of her loans in animal-raising. At present besides this business, her family catches fish. Therefore, they have a stable income of VND 3 million/month. For the next loan cycle, she wants to borrow VND 9 million to buy some implements for fishing.

loans.use: to buy some implements for fishing

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 43-year-old Mary M. from Mwanza.  Married with four children between the ages of seven and twenty, Mary has been running a grocery business selling water, soda, biscuits, flours, and sugar since 2005. Working at the business 16 hours a day, seven days per week and assisted by husband, she currently earns about $400 each month. She is requesting a loan of $950 in order to buy more soda, flours, sugar, and water, and in the future plans to increase the quantity and range of her stock. Mary thanks you for your support!

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets; thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro leasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To buy more soda, flours, sugar, and water.

loans.name: Sam

texts.en: Mrs. Sam S. is a farmer in the Kampong Chrey Village in Takeo Province. In her plantation, she now faces a small problem because her plantation field has infertile soil. So she decided to ask for a loan to purchase fertilizer to make her field more productive. In addition to farming, she owns a small grocery store in the local village. Her husband, Mr. Hor Khloeun, is a construction worker who makes $2.50 per day, a very small income to support his family. Mrs. Sam S. is 27 years old and the mother of three children, two of whom attend the local school while the youngest one is too young for school. Her husband is on the right in the photo.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer.

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.en: Mrs. Nguyen Thi N. joined TYM in 2004. At first she borrowed VND 500,000 to raise livestock. Now, after 4 years with TYM Fund, her family invests most of the loans in animal raising. This business is doing well and brings in a stable annual income. Her husband is a commune electrician; her children are grown-up and have stable jobs. Therefore, with their own income and financial assistance from their children, she and her husband have an income of VND 2.5 million per month. For the next cycle, she is applying for VND 9 million to invest in animal raising.

loans.use: to invest in animal raising

loans.name: Pham Thi

texts.en:
Mrs. Pham Thi V., aged 25, joined TYM Fund in 2004. Accessing her first loan, she applied for VND 2 million to buy implements for fishing. This is now the main source of income for Mrs. V.'s family. Besides this, she raises animals and grows rice to generate more income for the family.

Although she is very young, she knows how to do business and earns a stable income of VND 3 million per month. The next loan cycle is coming and she wants to access VND 9 million to buy some more implements for fish catching.

loans.use: to buy some more implements for fish catching

loans.name: Ath

texts.en: Mrs. Ath S. lives in Kampong Chrey Village in Takeo Province. She is a farmer who faces a problem because her rice field is infertile. To solve this problem, Mrs. Ath S. decided to ask for a loan to purchase fertilizer to support her rice plantation and produce a better crop. Aside from this farming, she sells fish in the local market. Her husband, Mr. Sam Sophaot, is a driver. Mrs. Ath S. is 38 years old and the mother of four children who are all attending the local school. Her husband is on the left of the photo.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer.

loans.name: Tran Thi

texts.en: Mrs. Tran Thi A. joined TYM in 2004. Since then she has borrowed several loans and invested most of them in animal-raising. Nowadays, in addition to this business, Mrs. A. weaves bamboo baskets while her husband works for other people to generate more income. With an income of VND 2.5 million/month, her family's living standard has been improving gradually. Now she wants to borrow VND 9 million to buy breeding animals and cattle-feed.

loans.use: to buy breeding animals and cattle-feed.

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is twenty-nine-year-old Esther M. from Mwanza. She is married. Esther has been running a voucher business since 2006. This client's business is selling vouchers, chargers, and phone accessories. She works at the business for twelve hours per day, six days per week and is assisted by one employee. Esther currently earns about US$ 300 from her business. She is requesting a loan of US$ 450 in order to buy more vouchers and phone accessories. In the future, she plans to increase the quantity and range of her stock. Esther thanks you for your support! SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility.

Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

One of the primary advantages of microleasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To buy more vouchers and phone accessories

loans.name: Prak

texts.en: Mrs. Prak N. owns a small grocery store in the local market which is located in Kampong Chrey Village in Takeo Province. Aside from this business, she is a farmer who faces an obstacle because the soil in her field is infertile. To solve this problem, Mrs. Prak N. decided to ask for a loan to purchase fertilizer. Her husband, Mr. Cheang Mok, is a construction worker who earns $2.50 per day, a very small income to support his household. Mrs. Prak N. is 46 years old and the mother of a child who helps her in both the plantation and the grocery business. Her husband is on the left in the photo.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer

loans.name: Lay

texts.en: Mrs. Lay S. owns a small grocery store in the local market which is located in Kampong Chrey Village in Takeo Province. Aside from this business, she is a farmer. Last year, she got $450 from her rice revenue. She is a 41-year-old widow with two children who attend the local school. She is now in poor conditions and lives in an uncomfortable house. Mrs. Lay S. wants to build a new house to replace the old one, so she decided to ask for a loan to buy timbers to build a new house for her household.

loans.use: To build a new house for her household.

loans.name: Tran Thi

texts.en: Mrs. Tran Thi H. is 30 years old. Before, her family had many financial difficulties as both she and her husband were workers but they did not have work regularly. In 2006 she joined TYM and borrowed VND 2 million to raise pigs. Today they earn an income of VND 2 million from this business. However, she thinks that she still has time to carry out another income-generating project. After observing and learning from the experience of other people, she plans to sell mats. Therefore, in the coming time, she wants to borrow VND 7 million for her husband to start up this new business.

loans.use: to start up a mat-selling business

loans.name: Bun

texts.en: Mrs. Bun C. is a farmer in Kampong Chrey Village in Takeo Province. Aside from this business, she is a pig breeder. Since the pig business is going well, she wants to expand it, so she decided to ask for a loan to buy eight more pigs for breeding. Each pig costs $50. With rest of the loan, she will buy pig food to feed her pigs. Mrs. Bun C. is a 59-year-old widow with two children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory and the other one is attending the local school.

loans.use: To buy more pigs and pig food.

loans.name: Van Thi

texts.en: Mrs. Van Thi N., 42, lives in Quang Trach commune, Quang Xuong district, Thanh Hoa province. In 2006, she joined TYM and borrowed VND 3 million to raise pigs. Because her husband is very experienced in animal raising, their business is developing and becoming more profitable. With an income of VND 3 million/month, her family's economy is getting more and more stable. That is why they are able to spend more on their children's education. For the next cycle, she has applied for a loan of VND 9 million ($550 USD) to invest in pig raising.

loans.use: To invest in pig raising.

loans.name: Mark

texts.en:
This is the second time Mrs. Mark S. has taken out the loan to improve her business. She is a farmer in the Prey Melong Cheng Village in Takeo Province. Mrs. S. is 28 years old and the mother of four children, three of whom are enrolled in the local school while the youngest one is still too young. Her husband, Mr. Maing Pork, is a fisherman who can make $1.50 per day, which is too little income to support his family. (He is on the left in the photo.)

It is the rainy season now and Mrs. S. wants to cultivate rice on the plantation. Unfortunately, she cannot do this because she does not have enough animals to plow the field. Thus, she decided to ask for a loan to buy another cow to add to the old one and use them as draft animals. She would use the rest of the money to buy fertilizers to support her rice field later.

loans.use: To buy another cow and fertilizer.

loans.name: Vu Thi

texts.vi: Mrs. Vu Thi N. is 39 years old. She joined TYM Fund in 2006. At present, besides farming, Mrs. N. and her husband operated a milling machine to husk rice for local people. With an income of VND 3 million/month, she can repay her loans and pay for the family's expenses every week. For the next loan cycle, she applis for VND 10 million to buy one more milling machine to better meet the demand of other villagers.

loans.use: buy one more milling machine

loans.name: Thị Lượng Chu Group

texts.vi:
Chị C. Thị Lượng 26 tuổi mã số 09050069 chị đi làm thuê òn chồng buôn bán hàng hóa. Chị cùng cả nhóm đã hoàn trả hết C. kỳ 1 và tiếp tục vay 3.808.000đ thời hạn 12 tháng để thêm vốn cho chồng đi chợ. thu nhập gia đình chị mỗi ngày từ 100.000 _120.000đ, với số tiền đó chị có thể chi tiêu cho gia đình và trả góp hàng tuần.Trong nhóm chị còn có 5 thành viên khác.

  • Ngô thị Nguyên mã số 09050070 vay 3808.000đ thời gian 12 tháng đê mua lợn giống và cám lợn.
  • Ngô thị Hà mã số 09050072 vay 3.808.000đ để mua cám.
  • Ngô Thị Thảo mã số 09050068 vay 3.808.000đ để mua lợn giống.
  • Ngô thị Ninh mã số 09050044 vay 3.660.000 để mua cám nuôi vịt đẻ trứng
  • T. Thị Lan mã số 09050115 vay vốn để đi chợ buôn bán hang tạp hóa như mỳ chính, kẹo bánh...
texts.en:
Mrs C. Thị Lượng is 26 years old. She works on contract. Her husband sells basic goods. Her group has already paid back their first loan. She is requesting a loan of 3.808.000 VND for her husband to invest in his business. Her family income is 100.000 - 120.000 VND a day. This is used to pay for daily expenses and the weekly payment. Her group has 5 other members:
  • Ngô thị Nguyên, seeking 3808.000 VND to buy breeding pigs and feed.
  • Ngô thị Ha, seeking 3.808.000đ VND to buy feed
  • Ngô Thị Thảo, seeking 3.808.000 VND to buy brreding pigs
  • Ngô thị Ninh, seeking 3.660.000 VND to buy feed for her ducks
  • T. Thị Lan , she sells basic goods

    • Translated from Vietnamese by Khang Ho-Si, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: buy basic goods to resell

loans.name: Debora

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is forty-six year old Debora M. from Mwanza. She is married with seven children, between the ages of eight and thirty-five. Debora has been running a grocery business since 2005. Her business is selling soda, biscuits, tea leaves, sugar, and flour. She works at the business for sixteen hours per day, six days per week. Debora currently earns about US$ 200 from her business. She is requesting a loan of US$ 450 in order to buy maize flour, soda, rice, and wheat flour. In the future, she plans to increase the quantity and range of of her stock. Debora thanks you for your support!

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro leasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To buy maize flour, soda, rice, and wheat flour

loans.name: Hoang Thi

texts.vi: Mrs. Hoang Thi T. is 39 years old. She has been in TYM Fund since 2005. She used her first loan with TYM to raise pigs. This business developed well and brought about a stable income for the family. After 3 years investing in thus business, Mrs. T. now has a stable income of VND 2.5 million/month. She wants to borrow VND 9 million to invest more in pig raising.
texts.en:
Note: the original description is in English.

Translated from Vietnamese by Khang Ho-Si, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: raise pigs

loans.name: Keo

texts.en: Mrs. Keo C. lives in Roluos Village in Takeo Province. She owns a small grocery store in the local village and she is also a farmer. In her plantation, she now face a small problem because the soil in her field is infertile. To solve this problem, Mrs. Keo C. decided to ask a loan to buy fertilizer. Her husband, Mr. Khoem Sovann, is a teacher who can make $50 per month. Mrs. Keo C. is 28 years old and the mother of two children, both of whom are too young to go to school. Mrs. Keo C.'s family is shown in the photo.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer

loans.name: Le Thi

texts.vi: Mrs. Le Thi H., aged 46, joined TYM Fund in 2003. At present, in addition to farming, her family invests in groundnut trading. Every day with the assistance of her husband and two grown-up children, her business goes on well and generates an income of VND 3 million. For the next loan cycle, she wants to borrow VND 13 million to invest more in groundnut trading to increase her family's economy.
texts.en:
Note: the original description is in English.

Translated from Vietnamese by Khang Ho-Si, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to invest more in groundnut trading

loans.name: Toem

texts.en: This is the second time of Mrs. Toem S. has asked for a loan to improve her living conditions. She owns a small grocery store in the local market, which is located in Pery Melong Cheng Village in Takeo Province. Her husband, Mr. Keo Samnang, is a farmer. Even though Mrs. Toem S. and her husband have different businesses, they still cannot support the family well, so Mrs. Toem S. decided to ask for a loan to buy two cows in order to start a breeding business. Mrs. Toem S. is 59 years old and the mother of a child who is attending the local school. Previously, Mrs. Toem S. obtained a $75 loan to start grocery business. She has paid it back fully. Her husband is on the left in the photo.

loans.use: To buy two cows

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.en: Mrs. Nguyen Thi L. is 45 years old. She and her husband have four children, two of whom are at school. Mrs. L. has been in TYM since 2003. Up to now, she has used most of her loans to raise chickens and pigs. With experience gathered over years, her business is now developing and getting more and more stable. With an income of VND 2 million/month, her famiL.'s life has been improved. For the next loan cycle, she wants to borrow 9 million to buy more chickens and pigs to expand her business.

loans.use: Raising

loans.name: Duk

texts.en:
This is the second time Mrs.Duk S. has taken out a loan to improve her business. She is a farmer in Prey Melong Cheng Village in Takeo Province. Mrs. S. is 49 years old and the mother of four children; two are employed in a garment factory and two are attending the local school.

In her plantation, she now cannot grow rice because she does not have enough animals to plow and cultivate. Thus, she decided to ask for a loan to hire a laborer with two oxen to deal with this problem. Mrs. S. would use the rest of the loan to buy fertilizers and pesticides for her crop. Her husband, Mr. Chen Then, helps her in plantation. He is pictured on the right in the photo.

loans.use: To hire a laborer with two oxen.

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi: Mrs. Nguyen Thi L. is 43 years old. She joined TYM Fund in 2004. By borrowing loans and using them effectively, she has improved her family's economy remarkably. Currently, besides farming, her family operates a modern set of milling machine to serve increasing demand of local people. With a desire that her family's life will be further improved, she applies for VND 15 million to buy one more machine and some tools for this business.
texts.en:
Note: the original description is in English.

Translated from Vietnamese by Khang Ho-Si, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy one more machine and some tools for business.

loans.name: Vann

texts.en: Mrs. Vann S. lives in Prey Tamao Village in Takeo Province. She is a farmer who now faces a small problem because her plantation field is infertile. To solve this problem, Mrs. Vann S. decided to ask for a loan to purchase fertilizer to support her field. In addition, she will use part of the loan to buy pesticides to protect her crops from all kinds of insects. Her husband, Mr. Yort Saroeurn, is a lottery seller who makes a small income to support his household. Mrs. Vann S. is 29 years old and the mother of three children who are all attending the local school. Her husband is on the left in the photo.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer and pesticides.

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi: Mrs. Nguyen Thi L. is 44 years old. She joined TYM in 2004 to borrow loans to raise chickens. As she can take advantage of available chicken-feed at home, her family's chicken raising business has been very effective with an average income of VND 2.5 million. For the next loan cycle, she wants to borrow VND 10 million to buy more breeding chickens and pigs and animal-feed to expand her raising business and generate more income for the family.
texts.en:
Note: the original description is in English.

Translated from Vietnamese by Khang Ho-Si, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: buy sows and chickens

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 36 years old. Elizabeth M. from Mwanza. She is married with three children, between the ages of 8 and 16. She has been running a pharmacy shop and dispensary since 2000. The name of the dispensary is K.M.T She works at the business for 16 hours per day, 7 days per week and she is assisted by her husband. Elizabeth currently earns about $250USD from her business. She is requesting a loan of $450USD to purchase more medicines such as quinine, panadol, glucose, and amoxylen. In the future, she plans to expand the business. Elizabeth thanks you for her support!

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of microleasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future

loans.use: To purchase more medicines.

loans.name: Hoang Thi

texts.vi: Mrs. Hoang Thi H. is 33 years old. She and her husband are both farmers. They have two small children. In 2005, to enhance the family's economy, Mrs. H. joined TYM Fund and borrowed loans to raise pigs. At first, with small loans, she just raised 5 pigs. After 3 years, now she can avail bigger loans and expand her business with 20 pigs in her pigpen and more bran reserved at home. Therefore, her family's income also increases up to VND 3 million/month. For the next loan cycle, she applies for VND 9 million to invest more in pig raising.
texts.en:
Note: the original description is in English

Translated from Vietnamese by Khang Ho-Si, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Raising

loans.name: Lang

texts.en: This is the second loan Mrs. Lang S. has taken out to improve her business. She is a farmer in Prasath Village in Takeo Province. In her plantation field, she now faces an obstacle because her field is too far from irrigation and she does not have any way to water her field. Thus, she decided to ask for a loan to buy a pump that she can use to water her field. Her husband, Mr. Koeb Minsuor, is a poultry breeder who raises ducks. Mrs. Lang S. is 38 years old and the mother of ten children, two of whom are employed in a garment factory, seven are attending the local school, and the youngest one is a newly born baby. Her husband is on the left of the photo.

loans.use: To ask for a loan to buy a pump in order to generate water to water her field.

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.en: Mrs. Nguyen Thi T. is 53 years old. In 2005, she joined TYM Fund and accessed a loan to raise chickens and pigs and plant fruit trees. As she has a very big garden, besides planting fruit trees like longan trees and banana trees, her family grows vegetables, which are used for pig raising. With the assistance of her husband and children, her business proves more and more effective. For the next loan cycle, she is applying for VND 8 million to buy more pigs and fertilizer to raise pigs and grow vegetables.

loans.use: Raising pigs and growing vegetables

loans.name: Meak

texts.en: This is the second time that Mrs. Meak R. has asked for a loan to improve her living conditions. She lives in Thmei Village in Takeo Province. She and her husband, Mr. Srey Saroeurn, are farmers. In their plantation, they cannot cultivate rice because they do not have enough animals to plow the rice field. Thus, Mrs. Meak R. has decided to ask for a loan to buy one more ox to add to their present one in order to plow the field to cultivate rice. Mrs. Meak R. is 60 years old and the mother of a child who helps her in the plantation. Her husband is shown in the left in the photo.

loans.use: to buy another ox to add to their old one to plow their field to cultivate rice

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi: Mrs. Nguyen Thi L. is 37 years old. At present both she and her husband grow rice and raise animals at home. In 2005, Mrs. L. joined TYM Fund and borrowed a loan to raise pigs to increase her family's economy. During three years, while raising pigs, she learned experience in cow raising. Now she and her husband bravely invest in cow raising and at first this business is effective. For the next loan cycle, she wants to borrow VND 7 million to invest in animal raising. With an income of VND 2 million/month, she ensures that she can repay regularly.
texts.en:
Note: the original description is in English.

Translated from Vietnamese by Khang Ho-Si, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: raise cows

loans.name: Phan

texts.en: Mrs. Phan S. is a villager in Tatai Village in Takeo Province. She is a pig breeder and her husband, Mr. Neav Sophorn, is a farmer. Since Mrs. Phan S.'s pig breeding is going well, she wants to expand so she decided to ask for a loan to buy five more pigs, which cost $87.50. With the rest of the loan she would use to buy more pig food to feed them. Mrs. Phan S. is 36 years old and she is married without any children. Her husband is presented on the left of the photo.

loans.use: To ask for a loan to buy five more pigs for breeding.

loans.name: Dinh Thi

texts.vi: Mrs. Dinh Thi N. is 49 years old. In 2004, she joined TYM Fund to borrow a loan to raise pigs. Thanks to her diligence and clever use of loans, her family's economy has increased obviously. At present, in addition to pig raising, her family has a small grocery offering some kinds of goods to students. For the next loan cycle, she applies for VND 10 million, part of which will be used to raise pigs and the rest used to buy more goods for the grocery
texts.en:
Note: the original description was in English.

Translated from Vietnamese by Khang Ho-Si, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: part of which will be used to raise pigs and the rest used to buy more goods for the grocery

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi: Mrs. Nguyen Thi H. is 41 years old. In 2004, she joined TYM Fund and borrowed loans to invest in her restaurant. Every day her husband buys raw food from agents and she uses these raw food to make dishes for customers. With high quality dishes, reasonable prices and enthusiastic service, her restaurant always attract a great number of customers and brings about an income of VND 3 million. For the next loan cycle, she wants to borrow VND 12 million to buy more raw food and kitchen ware for her restaurant.
texts.en:
Note: the original description is in English.

Translated from Vietnamese by Khang Ho-Si, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Invest in her restaurant

loans.name: Jesca

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 34-year-old Jesca S. from Mwanza. Married with three children between the ages of three and ten, Jesca has been running a poultry-selling business since 2000. Working ten hours a day, six days per week and assisted by one employee, she currently earns about $200 monthly from her business. Jesca is requesting a loan of $1050 to buy 500 chickens, and in the future plans to buy even more. She thanks you for your support!

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility.

loans.use: To buy 500 chickens

loans.name: Mao

texts.en:
Mrs. Mao A. is a farmer in Trapaing Svay Village in Takeo Province. Her husband, Mr. Puok Noeurn, owns a small grocery store in the local market. Although Mrs. Mao A. and her husband have different businesses, they still cannot support their family well. In order to improve their living conditions, Mrs. Mao A. decided to ask for a loan to add to her savings to buy a motorbike to start motorbike taxi.

Mrs. Mao A. is 29 years old and the mother of two children, one of whom is enrolled in the local school while the younger, who is one year old, is too young to study. Mrs. Mao A.'s family is shown in the picture.

loans.use: To add to her savings in order to buy a motorbike to start motorbike taxi.

loans.name: Sal

texts.en:
Mrs. Sal O., 38, makes brooms for sale from her house. She makes about 40 brooms per day and sells US$0.25 for one. She has been making and selling brooms for about eighteen years. With her long experience, she can earn approximately US$5.00 per day, while her husband, Mr. Phally Chon, 44, is car driver for a company. Sal has five children, two of whom are construction workers and another son is gasoline station staff, living in Kdol Donteav Commune in the Battambang Province.

Sal faces difficulty to attract her clients come to buy brooms from her house. To overcome this obstacle, she decided to seek a loan of US$1,200 to use for decorating house to make easier for making broom and also attract her customers. The remainder of loan is being used to add her capital for making brooms. The loan will improve the family's income through expanding her broom selling business.

loans.use: To use for decorating house to make easier for making brooms and also attract customers

loans.name: Witness B.

texts.en:
Mambo from Mbeya, Tanzania! This is 44-year-old Witness S., who is married and has four children aged between 23 and 15. In 2005, Witness established her genge (see below) business. Working six days a week, 13-16 hours a day, and assisted by her husband, she earns about $40 every month from this business.

Witness is requesting a loan to purchase more rice, sugar, salt and cooking oil in bulk, and in the future plans to establish another business. She thanks you for your support.

The Swahili word for this type of outside shop, or stall, is genge. A genge is usually a very basic structure made of wood, with a tin roof, which sells general items such as onions, tomatoes, chili, oil, rice, and dried fish. It is the kind of place local people usually send their children running to in order to fetch something when they are in the middle of cooking the evening meal and don't have time to go all the way to the market to buy the missing ingredient.

loans.use: To purchase more rice, sugar, salt and cooking oil in bulk.

loans.name: Roeung

texts.en:
Mrs. Roeung C. is a villager in Prothorng Village in Takeo Province. She is 26 years old and the mother of a three year old child who is too young for school. She is a farmer who can make a little revenue from rice because she owns a small field. Her husband, Mr. Mao Kan, is a construction worker who can make $4 a day. He is shown on the left in the picture.

Even though Mrs. C. and her husband each have businesses, they still cannot afford to build a new house. Thus, Mrs. C. decided to ask for a loan to buy timbers to build a new house to replace the old one.

loans.use: To buy timber to build a new house.

loans.name: Baby

texts.fr: Baby D. est âgée de 48 ans, mariée et mère de 5 enfants. Elle est revendeuse de légumes à Adeta, un village situé à environ 150 kilomètres de Lomé, la capitale togolaise. Pour mieux répondre à la demande de sa clientèle et augmenter la capacité de son commerce, Baby désire avec ce crédit, acheter des légumes auprès des jardiniers pour la revente. Cette chance lui permettra d’intervenir dans la prise en charge des dépenses du foyer.
texts.en:
Baby D., 48, is married and the mother of 5 children. She sells vegetables in Adeta, a village situated about 150 km from Lomé, the capital of Togo. In order to better respond to the demand from her clientele and expand the capacity of her business, Baby wants to use this loan to buy vegetables from market gardeners for re-sale. This will allow her to start paying expenses for her household.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: buying vegetables
